Today is Friday, March 21, the 80th day of 2025. There are 285 days left in the year.

Today in history:

On March 21, 1965, civil rights demonstrators led by the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. began their third attempt to march from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama — this time under the escort of U.S. Army and National Guard troops assigned by President Lyndon B. Johnson.

Also on this date:

In 1952, the Moondog Coronation Ball, considered the first rock and roll concert, took place at Cleveland Arena.

In 1963, the United States closed Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary; over 1,500 inmates had been jailed at the island prison off the coast of San Francisco, California over its three decades of use.

In 1980, President Jimmy Carter announced that the United States would boycott the Summer Olympic games in Moscow because of the Soviet Union’s failure to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan.

In 1990, Namibia became an independent nation as the former colony marked the end of 75 years of South African rule.

In 2012, meting out unprecedented punishment for a bounty system that targeted key opposing players, the NFL suspended New Orleans Saints head coach Sean Payton without pay for the coming season and indefinitely banned the team’s former defensive coordinator; NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell fined the Saints $500,000 and took away two draft picks.

In 2019, President Donald Trump abruptly declared that the U.S. would recognize Israel’s sovereignty over the disputed Golan Heights — the first country to do so — in a major shift in American policy.

In 2022, a China Eastern Boeing 737 aircraft with 132 people on board crashed in a mountainous area of southern China, setting off a forest fire visible from space in the country’s worst air disaster in decades. (All 123 passengers and nine crew members would later be confirmed dead.)

2025 MAR 21 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Math Daily News -- Data detailed on remote sensing have been presented. According to news reporting out of Kunming, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "This study aimed to accurately map burned forest areas and analyze the spatial distribution of forest fires under complex terrain conditions."


Funders for this research include National Natural Science Foundation of China; Agricultural Joint Foundation of Yunnan Province.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Southwest Forestry University: "This study integrates Landsat 8, Sentinel-2, and MODIS data to map burned forest areas in the complex terrain of western Yunnan. A machine learning workflow was developed on Google Earth Engine by combining Dynamic World land cover data with official fire records, utilizing a logistic regression-based feature selection strategy and an enhanced SNIC segmentation GEOBIA framework. The performance of four classifiers (RF, SVM, KNN, CART) in burn detection was evaluated through a comparative analysis of their spectral-spatial discrimination capabilities. The results indicated that the RF classifier achieved the highest performance, with an overall accuracy of 96.32% and a Kappa coefficient of 0.951. Spatial analysis further revealed that regions at medium altitudes (800-1600 m) and moderate slopes (15-25°) are more prone to forest fires."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This study demonstrates a robust approach for generating accurate large-scale forest fire maps and provides valuable insights for effective fire management in complex terrain areas."
For more information on this research see: Mapping Burned Forest Areas in Western Yunnan, China, Using Multi-Source Optical Imagery Integrated with Simple Non-Iterative Clustering Segmentation and Random Forest Algorithms in Google Earth Engine. Remote Sensing, 2025,17(5):741. (Remote Sensing - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/remotesensing/). The publisher for Remote Sensing is MDPI AG.

urn:contentItem:6D2F-X741-JBSP-13SH-00000-00Research on Landscape Ecology Published by a Researcher at European Forest Institute (Through Smoke to Policy: Framing the EU Forest Fire Policy Landscape)2024-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:07:19ZLexisNexisECOLOGY - LANDSCAPE ECOLOGYResearch on Landscape Ecology Published by a Researcher at European Forest Institute (Through Smoke to Policy: Framing the EU Forest Fire Policy Landscape)


2024 SEP 27 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Fresh data on landscape ecology are presented in a new report. According to news reporting from Wien, Austria, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "The global community is grappling with a significant increase in forest fires' frequency, size, and intensity, presenting a profound challenge."


Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from European Forest Institute: "To complement existing framing literature on forest fires, this paper examines collective frames applied to forest fires in a broader EU context. Employing a content analysis covering 354 EU policy documents-spanning both soft (non-legally binding) and hard (legally binding) policy documents-via the use of Atlas.ti, six collective frames on forest fires are outlined, identifying four as particularly dominant: ‘climate adaptation and resilience', ‘risk mitigation and protective governance', ‘agriculture and rural development', and ‘technocratic perspectives on forest fires'. These frames capture dominant perspectives promoted within specific policy domains, such as energy and agriculture. Despite the diverse approaches to framing forest fires and their varied objectives, a common thread connects the narratives in these documents, namely, the central theme of ‘risk'."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Whether it emerges in the context of reporting or as part of a call to action for adopting certain EU measures, the use of risk operates as a narrative device that negatively frames the discourse, consistently employed to call for action. The findings underscore the importance of considering communication strategies surrounding forest fires, particularly in light of their implications for forest governance."
For more information on this research see: Through Smoke to Policy: Framing the EU Forest Fire Policy Landscape. Land, 2024,13(9). (Land - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/land). The publisher for Land is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/land13091450.

urn:contentItem:6FR4-6BD3-S2CX-S2V0-00000-00EXPERT: REPEATED STRIKES TO NICHOLS' HEAD WERE EXCESSIVE2025-05-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:07:19ZLexisNexisASECTIONPg. A-16EXPERT: REPEATED STRIKES TO NICHOLS' HEAD WERE EXCESSIVECompiled from news services

A police training expert testifying Saturday as a defense witness in the trial of three former Memphis officers charged in the fatal beating of Tyre Nichols acknowledged that kicks and punches to Nichols' head were unnecessary and excessive.

Don Cameron took the stand on the sixth day of the trial of Tadarrius Bean, Demetrius Haley and Justin Smith, who have pleaded not guilty to state charges including second-degree murder. They already face the prospect of years in prison after they were convicted of federal charges last year.

Nichols, a 29-year-old Black man, fled a January 2023 traffic stop after he was yanked out of his car, pepper-sprayed and hit with a Taser. Five officers who are also Black caught up with him and punched, kicked and hit Nichols with a police baton, struggling to handcuff him as he called out for his mother near his home.

Footage of the beating captured by a police pole camera also showed the officers milling about, talking and laughing as Nichols struggled. His death led to nationwide protests, calls for police reforms in the U.S., and intense scrutiny of police in Memphis, a majority-Black city.

Mr. Cameron was called to the stand by the defense lawyer for Haley, who was at the traffic stop and arrived at the location of the beating after former officer Emmitt Martin kicked and punched Nichols in the head as Nichols was being held by Smith and Bean.

Mr. Cameron said Nichols had not yet been handcuffed and Haley used proper force in kicking Nichols once in the arm. The veteran police trainer said Haley kicked Nichols in order to facilitate the handcuffing of Nichols by the other officers.

However, under cross-examination by prosecutor Paul Hagerman, Mr. Cameron acknowledged that the punches and kicks by Martin to Nichols' head were unnecessary, excessive and an example of deadly force. Officers who saw those head blows had a duty to intervene and stop the beating at that point, Mr. Cameron said.

Texas Gov. Abbott signs $1B school voucher bill

Texas will implement a $1 billion school voucher program, one of the largest in the country, that uses public dollars to fund private school tuition under a bill Gov. Greg Abbott signed Saturday, capping off a yearslong effort by Republicans.

School voucher supporters have long targeted the state, where past efforts buckled for decades against resistance from Democrats and rural Republicans. Last month President Donald Trump called lawmakers before a key vote needed to finally get the bill to Abbott's desk.

Texas joins more than 30 other states that have implemented a similar program, of which about a dozen have launched or expanded their programs in recent years to make most students eligible.

School vouchers have been Mr. Abbott's primary focus this year, coming off a 2024 election cycle in which he led a campaign to oust GOP lawmakers who voted against a similar bill last session.

Republican lawmakers and bill supporters say it will give parents more choice by letting them pull their children out of poor-performing public schools.

"Gone are the days that families are limited to only the schools assigned by government," Mr. Abbott said before signing the bill at the governor's mansion. "The day has arrived that empowers parents to choose the school that is best for their child."

Second person charged with setting N.J. wildfire

A second person has been charged with arson in the wildfire in New Jersey's Pine Barrens that has grown into the state's second-largest fire in nearly two decades.

Prosecutors said Friday that a 17-year-old was arrested and charged with arson, aggravated arson and hindering apprehension. His name was not released because he is a juvenile.

The fire that has been burning for nearly two weeks is 80% contained, according to the state Forest Fire Service. The blaze in southern New Jersey's Ocean County has spread across 24 square miles. No injuries have been reported.

A 19-year-old man from Waretown was charged with arson a week ago. Prosecutors say Joseph Kling set wood pallets on fire and left the area. On Friday, prosecutors said Mr. Kling and a few other people took the pallets from a recycling center, drove to a heavily wooded area and used gasoline to start the fire.

Mr. Kling's attorney said at a detention hearing Friday that Mr. Kling did not intend to set the wildfire or destroy any property.

The Pine Barrens sit between Philadelphia and the Atlantic coast, a region with quick-draining sandy soil and trees with still-developing leaves where winds can kick up, drying out the forest floor.

2025 JAN 08 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Life Science Daily -- Investigators publish new report on soft computing. According to news originating from the Department of Business Management by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Abstracts: The study focuses on enhancing early detection and intelligent warning of forest fires by leveraging deep learning coupled with remote sensing imagery."


Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Department of Business Management: "The research adaptively enhances the genetic algorithm to optimize target detection algorithms for long and short-term memory networks. This approach aims to detect fire features from multi-temporal remote sensing data, enabling the construction of a forest fire early warning model. The experiment results indicated that the improved genetic algorithm stabilized fitness values by the 17th generation, significantly enhancing target detection efficiency and accuracy. The forest fire early warning model, developed using the improved genetic algorithm and remote sensing imagery, demonstrated impressive performance with only a 0.25 % absolute error between predicted and actual fire extent within the 11-318 m2 range. These findings suggest that the research model excels in providing precise early-stage warnings for small-scale forest fires."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The results of this research have significantly improved the response to sudden forest fires."

Abstract

Over the last decade, the number of forest fires in Brazil has been increasing continuously. In 2024, the number of forest fires in São Paulo state reached unprecedented levels. This phenomenon, combined with unfavorable conditions for pollutant concentrations, given temperature and precipitation anomalies, resulted in high concentrations of pollutants for several weeks, mainly affecting the number of hospitalizations of the most vulnerable age groups, children (due to respiratory diseases) and older adults (due to cerebrovascular diseases) in the city of São Paulo. The Incidence Rate Ratio calculations demonstrate how different age groups are differently affected by changes in pollutant concentrations and meteorological variables, so that air temperature, relative humidity, concentration of Particulate Matter, SO2, NO2, and O3 are the main variables that affect hospitalizations by respiratory, cerebrovascular or cardiovascular diseases.

IntroductionIn the last decades, the frequency and extent of forest fires have increased dramatically worldwide1. Large-scale wildfires were observed in California (USA) in 20082, Colorado (USA)3 and Valencia (Spain)4 in 2012, Canada5 and Portugal6 in 2017, and Southeast Australia in 2019–207. Anthropogenic activities, such as deforestation and pasture renovation or clearing, combined with extreme weather conditions like droughts and high air temperatures, have contributed to the occurrence and rapid spread of forest fires on an unprecedented scale and duration8,9. This combination of wildfires, particularly in tropical regions, unsustainable land use, and climate change, has caused a reinforcing effect due to a reduction in the Earth’s capacity to sink CO2, disrupting the regulation of this greenhouse gas. As a result, the reinforcing effect leads to increased warming, which is one of the factors for igniting new fire outbreaks10.

Over the last decade, Brazil has attracted significant attention due to the large number and extent of forest fires, ranking first in the number of wildfires in South America11. Among the various biomes in this country, the Amazon and the Atlantic Forest (the predominant biome in the state of São Paulo) deserve special attention, as both can be classified as fire-sensitive because fire harms their biodiversity12. Therefore, at these biomes, only adverse conditions related to extreme droughts make them more vulnerable to fire13. However, climate changes have caused anomalies in rainfall patterns, intensifying droughts in tropical and subtropical areas, particularly during severe El Niño/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events14, 15–16 and due to effects of Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) weakening17. When combined with unsustainable land use, such anomalies can increase the frequency and intensity of heat waves, providing more ignition sources for fires and lengthening the wildfire season. For instance, in 2020, over 312,140 km2 of the Brazilian territory was burned, with 46.3% and 28.6% of these fires concentrated in the Amazon and Cerrado biomes, respectively18. This same year, the Pantanal was also devastated by a severe fire, which affected about a third of its total area (around 40,606 km2)19.

Forest fires harm the local fauna and flora and directly impact public health through atmospheric pollution. Their harmful effects can range from eye irritation and corneal abrasions in nearby populations to a significant increase in hospitalizations and deaths caused by respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, even in regions up to 1000 km away7.

Wildfire events can significantly contribute to an increase in the concentration of carbon monoxide (CO) (generally confined to regions directly affected by the fire), methane (CH4), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and particulate matter (PM), particularly fine and ultrafine particles. These particles can travel long distances, causing harmful effects even in areas far from the fire’s origin20,21. Compared to urban PM, wildfire-generated PM contains higher levels of oxidative potential (e.g., oxygenated PAHs and quinones) and proinflammatory components (e.g., aldehydes and NOx).

The exposure to wildfire smoke can result in respiratory (bronchitis, pneumonia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD]), cardiovascular diseases (hypertension, heart stroke), and allergic and immunological disorders (Atopic dermatitis, Allergic rhinitis, and Asthma)22.

CO can form carboxyhemoglobin when it enters the human body. This compound impairs oxygen transport and can cause hypoxia, as well as having long-term toxic consequences for the body’s organs and tissues. Furthermore, CO can disrupt intracellular respiratory processes, resulting in cellular hypoxia. Carbon oxides bound to intracellular macromolecules have toxic effects on all body tissues23,24. NOx, mainly from wildfire smoke, can cause coughing and inflammation of airways, favoring the prevalence of asthma and COPD25,26. VOCs can be composed of several elements that are harmful to human health (eg, acrolein, benzene, formaldehyde, toluene, etc.). In addition, they can react with hazardous compounds, like peroxyacetyl nitrate (PAN), resulting in a compound that favors the eyes, nose, and throat irritation27,28. Prolonged exposure to high concentrations of O3 contributes to respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, especially in the most vulnerable populations29. SO2 can cause irritation and inflammation of the airways, affecting the respiratory system30. The exposure to high PM concentrations affects the cardiovascular, dermal, digestive, immune, nervous, respiratory, and reproductive systems29. However, compared to urban PM, wildfire-generated PM contains higher levels of oxidative potential (e.g., oxygenated PAHs and quinones) and proinflammatory components (e.g., aldehydes and NOx).

Furthermore, it is essential to highlight that as PM ages, its chemical composition changes, and its oxidative potential increases. As a result, PM generated by wildfires can become more toxic to macrophage cells as it travels, eventually reaching urban areas. Additionally, ultra-fine PM can pass through the alveolar membrane and penetrate deeper into the lungs. This can lead to changes in pulmonary responses, potentially affecting airway function and the body’s ability to resist viruses and bacteria. Consequently, hospital admissions and emergency visits for respiratory symptoms, mainly for asthma, bronchitis, dyspnea, pneumonia, and COPD symptoms increase significantly31, 32, 33, 34, 35–36. In addition, exposure to elevated levels of PM2.5 impairs vascular function, which can contribute to cardio and cerebrovascular diseases37.

Therefore, although other events, such as dust storms38, extreme pollen seasons39 or changes in local emission patterns40 have been reported in the literature as responsible for the increase in hospital admissions, fire events deserve to be highlighted due to the change that occurs in the toxicity of the particles, making them extremely harmful to the population, especially the most vulnerable one.

Figure S1 summarizes the interactions described above and demonstrates how combining several processes can increase the number of mobility and mortality cases associated with high temperatures and air pollution levels. Based on this scenario, the current study aims to investigate how the increase in the number of forest fires, between January and September 2024 in São Paulo Municipality, combined with atmospheric conditions less favorable to pollutant dispersion, mainly during winter, resulted in a high concentration of atmospheric pollutants, and consequently on variations in the number of hospitalizations by respiratory, cardiovascular, and cerebrovascular diseases.

Results

Wild fires and pollutant concentrations

Figure 1 shows the number of fires and fire foci observed in São Paulo state from January until September 2024 (gray stars), compared to the average values recorded from 2004 to 2023 (red lines). Since January, the observed values ​​have consistently exceeded the historical average several times, with this trend becoming even more concerning during the fire season. On some days, up to 2,000 fires or outbreaks have been recorded. The data observed in 2024 also indicate an extension of the fire season, which historically begins in July and ends in the middle of October. However, more fire events ​​have been observed since January this year. The increasing number of fires can be attributed to extreme drought conditions and high temperatures, recorded in Brazil’s southeast, central-west, and north regions in 2024. The figures S2 and S3 illustrate the temperature and precipitation anomalies for August and September, which coincided with the highest number of wildfires and/or fire spots. Both figures show meteorological conditions favorable to fires (higher temperature and reduced precipitation), particularly in the southeast, central-west, and north regions.Fig. 1

Number of Fire Events/Fire Forci from 2003 to 2024 in São Paulo state. The red line represents the daily average from 2004 to 2023, and the red shade depicts the standard deviation. The grey markers indicate the daily number of fire events in 2024. Note the change in the scale of fire events to reflect the elevated number in 2024 accurately.

Source: https://terrabrasilis.dpi.inpe.br/queimadas/bdqueimadas/.

The Fig. 2 presents the August and September (Figs. 2a and b, respectively) Ångstrom Matrices41, 42–43 for São Paulo Municipality. Small particles (PM2.5) and black carbon are observed in both months, with the latter detected through its differential Single Scattering Albedo (dSSA). Although black carbon can be produced locally from vehicle emissions, the presence of particles with greater absorption capacity suggests the occurrence of the lensing effect44. This process is associated with the aging aerosols transported from other regions, which become coated with secondary organic aerosols. The advection of smoke plumes from fires occurred in rural areas of São Paulo state and Midwest and north regions of Brazil, to São Paulo Municipality, especially during the fire season, has been reported in several previous studies21,45,46.Fig. 2

Ångström Matrix for São Paulo Municipality in 2024 (a) august and (b) september.

This information is complemented by Fig. 3, which shows the daily mean concentration of PM2.5, PM10, O3, SO2, NO2, and AOD values in São Paulo Municipality. As indicated in Fig. 1, the stars represent values registered from January to September 2024, while the red line shows the historical average value. Historically, higher concentrations of pollutants are observed in São Paulo during the winter months (June, July, and August) due to unfavorable conditions for pollutant dispersion (e.g., low convective boundary layer height, reduced wind speed, and absence of rain). Additionally, the average daily PM concentration often exceeds the national and international recommended daily limits between July and August, primarily due to the high number of biomass burning events, which advects smoke plumes to São Paulo Municipality, combined with the local emissions of air pollutants, as mentioned previously. In 2024, although the observed pattern is quite similar to the historical average PM concentration (Figs. 3a-b), it is evident that since May, the average daily concentrations have largely exceeded the historical average values, with a significant part surpassing the average standard deviation. From August onwards, the concentrations have predominantly remained above the average standard deviation. For PM2.5 and PM10, on certain days (23–25 September), the measured values were more than double the average standard deviation values. This pattern of higher values in 2024, compared to the historical time series, is also observed in O3 (Fig. 3c) and NO2 (Fig. 3e) (mainly in September).Fig. 3

Average daily concentration of PM2.5 (a), PM10 (b), O3 (c), SO2 (d), NO2 (e) and AOD (f) at São Paulo municipality.

On the other hand, SO2 (Fig. 3d) has a predominance of values below the average values, so September is the month with the higher number of days whose daily concentration is close to the average value provided by historical time series. This behavior results from reducing the sulfur content of fossil fuels, both industrial and automotive47. The higher AOD values (Fig. 3f) observed in 2024 are primarily due to the combination of adverse meteorological conditions (low air relative humidity, absence of rainfall) and wildfires, which together created less favorable conditions for pollutant dispersion, leading to increased concentrations of NO, NO2, NOx, and PM. In addition, the figure S4, derived from VIIRS satellite data, presents the Ultra Violet Aerosol Index values in Brazil on 23 September, showing high values (consequently high concentration of aerosols) in the Southeast, Midwest, and Northern regions. Unfortunately, field measurements of chemical compounds were not performed during 2024. Nevertheless, previous field campaigns in the Metropolitan Area of São Paulo have identified the presence of some biomass burning tracers such as levoglucosan, mannosan, and galactosan48, in the aerosol fine aerosol, in mass concentrations up to 1.2 µg m-3 (levoglucosan) during wintertime49,50. The authors concluded that São Paulo is impacted by regional sugarcane crop burning, what was also confirmed by analyzing air mass trajectories from the west and northwest, and by satellite measurements identifying hundreds of daily forest fires across the field campaigns.

Therefore, it can be concluded that the combination of unfavorable atmospheric conditions for the dispersion of pollutants and the increase in the number of fires resulted in higher concentrations of the pollutants shown in Fig. 3.

Variations in hospitalizations due to respiratory, cardiovascular, and cerebrovascular diseases

Figure 4 presents the incidence of respiratory (Fig. 4a), cerebrovascular (Fig. 4b), and cardiovascular (Fig. 4c) diseases recorded in DataSUS for São Paulo Municipality from 2000 to 2024. Respiratory diseases are most prevalent in children, followed by adults, and then older adults. These diseases exhibit seasonality, with a sharp increase at the beginning of autumn (March–May) and a significant reduction during the summer (December-February). From February to September 2024, the number of children diagnosed with respiratory diseases was higher than the average value observed from 2000 to 2023, particularly during the first week of April (302 in 2024 compared to an average of 247 between 2000 and 2023, a 21% increase) and the first week of September (267 cases in 2024 compared to an average of 151 between 2000 and 2023, a 77% increase). In addition, the average number of cases in 2024 (161 ± 70) was higher than the average ​​observed during the same months in 2000–2023 (150 ± 52). The same pattern was observed in older adults (60 ± 14 in 2024 compared to 48 ± 4 from 2000–2023), while the difference in adults was smaller (95 ± 46 during 2024 compared to 94 ± 27 from 2000–2023).Fig. 4

The dots represent the values observed in 2024, the dotted lines are the average from 2000 to 2023, and the shaded areas represent the standard deviation.

Source: DataSUS.

According to data extracted from DataSUS, cerebrovascular diseases in São Paulo (Fig. 4b) primarily affect older adults (101 ± 5 hospitalizations/year), followed by adults (57 ± 3 hospitalizations/year). The number of children diagnosed with these diseases is close to zero. From January to September 2024, hospitalizations in older adults consistently remained higher than the average observed between 2000 and 2023, with the average number of hospitalizations in 2024 (137 ± 28) being 34% higher than the previous years (56 ± 2). In the adult age group, although there was an increase (61 ± 14 in 2024 compared to 56 ± 2 from 200–2023), it is less significant (around 9%).

Similar to cerebrovascular diseases, cardiovascular diseases (Fig. 4c) primarily affect older adults (343 ± 29 hospitalizations/year), followed by adults (232 ± 14 hospitalizations/year). The number of children hospitalized due to cardiovascular diseases was close to zero. Among the three disease groups analyzed, this was the only one that showed a reduction in the number of hospitalizations compared to the period from January to September in 2000–2023. In the older adults, a reduction of around 5% was observed (311 ± 52 in 2024 compared to 327 ± 55 in 2000–2023), and in adults, the reduction was approximately 22% for adults (181 ± 28 in 2024 compared to 231 ± 22 from 2000–2023).

Discussion

In recent years, the combination of extreme events driven by climate change and unsustainable land use has led to a significant increase in both the frequency and intensity of forest fires, as well as the length of the fire season, in the Southeast, Midwest, and North states of Brazil.

This study showed that the intense drought and high temperatures observed between August (the end of the fire season) and September 2024 likely contributed to an increase in the occurrence of wildfires and an extension of the fire season. These factors led to more biomass-burning episodes during this period, exceeding the historical average by up to 50%. The increase in fires across several Brazilian regions (especially in the Midwest and North, which historically advect smoke plumes to São Paulo Municipality) resulted in higher emissions of pollutants (e.g., NO2, PM, SO2). Additionally, due to wintertime and the intense drought in September 2024, less favorable atmospheric conditions for pollutant dispersion led to elevated concentrations of pollutants in São Paulo Municipality.

Between January and September 2024, the number of hospitalizations due to respiratory or cerebrovascular diseases were higher than the average values ​​recorded over the previous 19 years, especially during the fire season. Children and older adults were among the age groups with the most significant variation in respiratory and cerebrovascular diseases, respectively, demonstrating that the most vulnerable groups were the most affected. Additionally, the calculation of the IRR allowed for a detailed analysis of how each pollutant and meteorological variable examined in this study impacts different age groups.

The relationship between PM2.5, NO2, and respiratory diseases, particularly in children, observed in São Paulo Municipality, has also been observed in previous studies conducted in other regions, such as South Africa51, Hong Kong52 and Western Amazon53.

Regarding the cerebrovascular diseases, the association between them and air temperature was also observed by Mascarenhas et al.54 in a study conducted in 10 Brazilian cities and by Doi et al.55 in Japan. Doi et al.55 also identified a positive relationship between relative humidity and cardiovascular diseases, particularly in older adults. Additionally, highlighting the capability of SO2 and O3 to cause oxidative stress, Hahad et al.56 and Miller57 also identified a relationship between these pollutants and cardiovascular diseases.

The relationship between pollutants, atmospheric variables, and cardiovascular diseases, observed in this study, align with previous studies carried out in São Paulo state58, China59, and Iran60. Furthermore, the positive relationship between temperature, relative humidity, and cardiovascular diseases has also been observed in other studies in northern and southern China61 and Taiwan62.

Therefore, the results presented in this study demonstrate how the increase of fires triggers a cascade effect that leads to higher pollutant concentrations and, consequently, an increase in hospitalizations due to respiratory and cerebrovascular diseases, particularly among the most vulnerable age groups. Moreover, the IRR results provide valuable insights into the potential health implications of a future warmer climate, especially for children and older adults.

Methods

Fire events

The daily number of fire incidents is sourced from the TerraBrasilis platform, developed by the National Institute for Space Research (INPE). The platform’s first version was launched in 2019. The platform aims to create a spatial data infrastructure specifically for monitoring data from the Amazon Rainforest Monitoring Program by Satellite (PRODES) and Real-Time Deforestation Detection System (DETER)63. All data are available at https://terrabrasilis.dpi.inpe.br/queimadas/bdqueimadas/, which contains records of all fire events detected by satellites and received by INPE since 1998. This study used data from reference satellites covering January 2004 to September 2024.

Pollutant concentration and atmospheric variables

The Environmental Company of the State of São Paulo (CETESB) operates an extensive network of fixed and mobile stations to monitor atmospheric pollutants across the state. The data from this network are made available through CETESB’s platform Qualar (https://qualar.cetesb.sp.gov.br/).

Concentration data for PM2.5, PM10, NO2, O3, and SO2, as well as, values of Air Temperature (T) and Relative Humidity (RH) were extracted from the Qualar platform. All data were collected from all 15 automatic monitoring stations in the São Paulo municipality. Hourly data between January 2004 and September 2024 were selected for this study, so that, from them the median (), maximum (), and mean () weekly values were then determined.

Ultra violet aerosol index and aerosol optical depth

The Ultra Violet Aerosol Index is a measurement of the amount of aerosol in the Atmosphere. In this study it was obtained from Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) data. VIIRS is part of the Suomi National Polar-orbiting Partnership (NPP)64, such instrument captures measurements across 22 spectral bands, spanning wavelengths from 0.41 to 12 µm. Among these, 16 are moderate-resolution bands with a nadir spatial resolution of 750 m, while 5 are imaging bands with a higher nadir spatial resolution of 375 m. Additionally, VIIRS features a unique day/night band in the reflective solar spectrum (0.5–0.9 µm), which operates at three different gain stages. This configuration enables an extensive dynamic range, allowing data collection during daytime and nighttime orbits65.

Using data from the Aerosol Robotic Network (AERONET), the Ångström matrix was estimated using the methodology described in Cappa et al.66. This matrix provides information about the type of aerosols and their absorption capacity, measured by the differential Single Scattering Albedo (dSSA). In addition, these same data were used to plot the daily Aerosol Optical Depth (AOD) [440 nm] time series (Fig. 4f) from January 2004 to September 2024.

Diseases

All disease data used in this work were collected from the DataSUS website (https://datasus.saude.gov.br/), a Brazilian Ministry of Health repository to São Paulo Municipality. The data were categorized into three age groups: children (0–14 years), adults (15–59 years), and older adults (60 years or older). The three groups of diseases analyzed comprise the following ICD codes: respiratory (J00, J01, J02, J03, J04, J05, J06, J11, J18, J20, J21, J22, 23, J30, J32, J40, J44, J45, J46, J47), cerebrovascular (I62, I63, I64, G45), and cardiovascular (I10, I11, I15, I20, I21, I24, I26, I45, I47, I48, I49, I50). The data covered the period from January 2000 to September 2024, and for analysis purposes, they were grouped into epidemiological weeks.

Incidence rate ratio (IRR)

The incidence rate ratio (IRR) was estimated using a univariate negative binomial regression. The outcome variable was the number of weekly hospitalizations to each age group (children, adults, and older adults), while the independent variables included the Mean, Median, and Maximum values of Air Temperature (T), Relative Humidity (RH), and concentrations of PM2.5, PM10, NO2, SO2, and O3. The initial negative binomial regression model included all variables. Variables with a P-value greater than 0.01 were removed using manual backward stepwise elimination. 2024 JUL 08 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Current study results on remote sensing have been published. According to news reporting out of Harbin, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "The timely and precise detection of forest fires is critical for halting the spread of wildfires and minimizing ecological and economic damage."


Funders for this research include National Key R&D Program of China; National College Students Innovation And Entrepreneurship Training Program.
Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Northeast Forestry University: "However, the large variation in target size and the complexity of the background in UAV remote sensing images increase the difficulty of real-time forest fire detection. To address this challenge, this study proposes a lightweight YOLO model for UAV remote sensing forest fire detection (LUFFD-YOLO) based on attention mechanism and multi-level feature fusion techniques: (1) GhostNetV2 was employed to enhance the conventional convolution in YOLOv8n for decreasing the number of parameters in the model; (2) a plug-and-play enhanced small-object forest fire detection C2f (ESDC2f) structure was proposed to enhance the detection capability for small forest fires; (3) an innovative hierarchical feature-integrated C2f (HFIC2f) structure was proposed to improve the model's ability to extract information from complex backgrounds and the capability of feature fusion. The LUFFD-YOLO model surpasses the YOLOv8n, achieving a 5.1% enhancement in mAP and a 13% reduction in parameter count and obtaining desirable generalization on different datasets, indicating a good balance between high accuracy and model efficiency."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This work would provide significant technical support for real-time forest fire detection using UAV remote-sensing images."
For more information on this research see: LUFFD-YOLO: A Lightweight Model for UAV Remote Sensing Forest Fire Detection Based on Attention Mechanism and Multi-Level Feature Fusion. urn:contentItem:6FFN-XC03-SCHM-H0V4-00000-00US at risk of losing health designation it’s had for 25 years2025-03-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:07:19ZLexisNexisUS NEWSUS at risk of losing health designation it’s had for 25 yearsAlix Martichoux

(NEXSTAR) – Measles was officially declared “eliminated” in the United States in 2000. If things keep going the way they’ve been going in 2025, that designation could soon change.

“Measles elimination status” is achieved in a country or region when there hasn’t been sustained transmission of the virus for a period of 12 months or longer, explained Dr. William Moss, an epidemiology professor at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health and director of the school’s International Vaccine Access Center, in a media briefing this month.

A country will lose that elimination status once an outbreak extends longer than a year, he said. We recently came close to crossing that threshold, but barely avoided it.

‘Disappointed but not surprised’: Measles cases explode in 19 states, new outbreak confirmed

“We’ve gone a quarter of a century with our measles elimination status,” Moss said. “We almost lost that in 2019 when this large outbreak in New York state and New York City almost extended beyond 12 months. It was just shy of 12 months.”

More than 1,200 measles cases were reported that year, largely in area without widespread vaccination, including Orthodox Jewish communities in New York.

So far this year, nearly 500 cases have been confirmed, and the number has been rising every week the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announces its new tally.

The largest outbreak of 2025 is in West Texas, where the virus has largely spread in undervaccinated Mennonite communities. Studies of past measles outbreaks in Amish communities indicate this wave of new cases could last many months or a year.

‘Like a forest fire’: Where large measles outbreaks will occur, according to an epidemiologist

Moss said it’s hard to say whether this year’s outbreak, which started in January, will last longer than 12 months, but it’s possible.

“I hope that is not the case and we can get a handle on this through increasing vaccination coverage but it does remain a threat and we could potentially lose our measles elimination status if this continues the way it has.”

In 1978, the CDC announced a goal of eliminating the highly contagious virus. The agency set a deadline for 1982.

The U.S. missed that deadline by quite a few years, but finally achieved elimination by 2000 “thanks to a highly effective vaccination program in the United States, as well as better measles control in the Americas region,” the CDC says.

Vaccine skepticism has increased since the COVID-19 pandemic, but there are early signs more people are getting vaccinated with against measles since the outbreaks in Texas and New Mexico began, the Associated Press reports.

urn:contentItem:6GD2-G853-RSWX-21NB-00000-00Risk assessment of corn borer based on feature optimization and weighted spatial clustering: a case study in Shandong Province, China2025-11-15T08:07:19Z2025-11-15T08:07:19ZLexisNexisRisk assessment of corn borer based on feature optimization and weighted spatial clustering: a case study in Shandong Province, China

Publisher’s noteSpringer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Abstract

As a typical pest affecting corn yield and safety, corn borer causes serious economic losses worldwide. Climate warming has intensified the occurrence of pest outbreaks in recent years, but the associated risk has not been precisely assessed or understood. To address this gap, this paper took Shandong Province, China as a case study, and constructed a feature optimization model for the class imbalance problem and a novel risk assessment method to quantify the temporal and spatial distribution of corn borer occurrence risk. Addressing the prevalent issue of class imbalance in pest datasets, a feature optimization model using Borderline-SMOTE to improve the Genetic Algorithm-Random Forest (GA-RF) was constructed, combined with Pearson correlation coefficient to jointly obtain a subset of features that affect corn borer. Subsequently, given the limitations of traditional risk assessment models that easily lose spatial information, by introducing the idea of weighted clustering algorithm, a novel machine learning model was proposed to assess the risk of agricultural pests and diseases.

Finally, integrating natural disaster risk theory, this paper achieved an assessment and zoning of corn borer risk in the study area based on hazard, sensitivity, disaster prevention and mitigation capacity, and comprehensive states. The results indicated that compared with the original RF model, the improved feature optimization model achieves increases of 18.64%, 11.12%, and 11.21% in OOB_score, Accuracy, and F1_score, respectively, and outperforms eight other benchmark models. In terms of clustering performance, the weighted K-means clustering algorithm achieves higher Silhouette coefficient by 0.0138 and 0.1885 compared with the weighted agglomerative hierarchical clustering algorithm (weighted AHC) and weighted DBSCAN, respectively, the Calinski-Harabasz index is higher by 3.8017 and 22.4039, and the Davies-Bouldin index is lower by 0.1006 and 0.4889, demonstrating superior clustering results. The spatial zoning results closely align with actual conditions. The risk of corn borer occurrence was concentrated in the southwest and northern areas of Shandong Province, while the risk in the central and southeast areas was relatively low. This research provides a novel approach to agricultural disaster risk assessment and the obtained results can serve as decision support for corn borer prevention and control in Shandong Province.

IntroductionDue to global warming, the suitable habitats for agricultural pests are expanding, and their development times are advancing continuously1. Agricultural pests can lead to a decrease in grain production, resulting in a series of societal issues. Therefore, it is of significant importance to assess the risk of pest occurrence systematically to enhance crop yields. Corn is one of the most crucial staple crops globally2. As a significant agricultural producer and consumer worldwide, China has a wide planting area for corn. In 2022 alone, the planting area of corn in China reached 43.07 million hectares, accounting for approximately 36.4% of the total grain planting area. The corn production amounted to 277.2 million tons, representing about 40.38% of the total grain production3,4. As a major province in both corn production and consumption, Shandong Province accounts for approximately 10% of China’s corn sown area and production5. The quantity of corn consumption and processing in Shandong consistently ranks first in China, exerting a significant influence on the national and even global corn market.

The corn borer, commonly known as the corn drill worm, is an important pest of grain crops such as corn, millet, and sorghum6. It causes harm by hiding and burrowing as larvae, damaging the undeveloped and rolled-up tender leaves during the whorl stage. Additionally, it inflicts harm after silk emergence by damaging the silks and female spikes. In its mature larval stage, it bores into corn stalks and female spikes, posing considerable challenges for prevention and control efforts7. Research indicates that in normal years, corn yield is reduced by 10–15% due to corn borer damage, and in years of severe infestation, the reduction can exceed 30%, leading to even complete crop failure8. According to statistics, the annual loss in corn production in China caused by the damage from corn borers is as high as 6 to 9 million tons (https://www.moa.gov.cn/ztzl). Predictably, pests like corn borer are a key agricultural disaster concern for cultivators of crops, especially in areas where agriculture serves as a pillar industry9, 10–11. In recent years, the intensifying trend of global warming has significantly enhanced the pest’s adaptability in northern China, increasing its overwinter survival rate, number of generations per year, and overall geographical distribution12,13. Consequently, climate change may have exacerbated the risk of corn borer outbreaks in Shandong Province. Pest disasters such as the corn borer have become critical threats requiring close monitoring in agricultural production, especially in areas that rely heavily on agriculture, where the pressure of prevention and control is particularly severe. Generally, the risk caused by agricultural pests and diseases can be mitigated to some extent through risk assessment and zoning, facilitating precise pesticide application by agricultural workers in practical operations14. Agricultural workers thus seek to enhance productive gains through accurate risk assessment and optimized management strategies15,16. However, to date, no studies have assessed the risk of corn borer from an integrated disaster risk assessment perspective. This study aims to fill that gap.

Disaster risk assessment involves dividing a particular area into zones of different risk levels, thereby formulating various disaster prevention and mitigation strategies to reduce the losses caused by disasters to human society17,18. It holds significant practical value in disaster risk management. Currently, it is widely used in various disaster fields such as floods, earthquakes, and landslides19, 20–21. From the perspective of research subjects, studies on disaster risk assessment can be divided into two main parts: one is the construction of the assessment indicators system, which includes the selection of assessment indicators and the determination of indicator weights18,22. In traditional risk assessment studies, the selection of evaluation indicators is typically performed manually by researchers based on theoretical foundations and existing research findings, combined with the specific characteristics of the disaster18,22,23. Appropriate evaluation indicators are selected to construct a risk assessment system, and methods such as expert scoring or analytic hierarchy process (AHP) are utilized to determine the weights of these indicators24,25. An apparent drawback of this approach is its susceptibility to subjective factors, resulting in the composition of the assessment system and the determined weights not being optimal26. Feature optimization enables the identification of the most relevant set of features to the target problem from a large pool, thereby enhancing the accuracy of results27. Zhang et al. utilized the correlation analysis (CA) and x-Loading weight method (x-Lw) to identify features related to leaf water content in winter wheat. Their results showed that the model achieved higher prediction accuracy compared to using all features28. In the context of pests and diseases research, the vast number of available features causes significant redundancy. Unfortunately, feature optimization methods have not yet been applied to risk assessment studies in agricultural pests and diseases research22.

The second aspect is the methodologies of risk assessment, encompassing the construction of assessment models and the division of risk levels. In previous studies, mathematical-statistical methods such as weighted comprehensive evaluation and natural disaster risk index method have often been used to establish assessment models22,29. These methods compute the risk index of the study area to represent its occurrence risk and utilize natural breaks classification (Jenks) to divide risk levels30,31. Although this approach is practical and has been widely applied in the field of natural disaster risk assessment, it simplifies complex assessment results into a single risk index or level, leading to the loss of significant spatial information and details. Moreover, the natural breaks classification method is the classification of one-dimensional data, and the method needs to preset the number of levels, which makes the classification results blind29. To address this issue, some scholars have introduced machine learning and deep learning algorithms to train sample sets and predict disaster risk probabilities or levels within the study area32, 33, 34, 35, 36–37. For example, Mishra et al. successfully predicted forest fire risk and its spatial distribution in Odisha, India using machine learning models, achieving high prediction accuracy and revealing important temporal trends38. Guria et al. further combined Sentinel-2 MSI data with ensemble machine learning methods to assess forest fire susceptibility and probability in the Similipal Biosphere Reserve39,40. These studies not only demonstrate the excellent performance of machine learning models in environmental risk assessment, but also highlight the significance of multiple conditioning factors and the application potential of advanced machine learning algorithms in the field of risk assessment. This type of method has high accuracy and applicability, but the training process requires known historical disaster risk probability or levels within the study area41, 42–43. In practice, many types of disasters and areas still lack official statistical risk levels and probabilities, preventing the widespread adoption and application of this method44. Therefore, there is an urgent need to explore a risk assessment model that can maintain high accuracy in the absence of historical risk probability levels. Clustering algorithms, as an unsupervised learning technique, cluster similar data points into a group, ensuring maximum similarity within a cluster while maintaining distinct differences between clusters45. Compared with traditional supervised learning methods such as Random Forest, Support Vector Machines, and Neural Networks, which rely heavily on labeled data, clustering methods are unsupervised learning approaches that offer significant advantages in situations where historical data and labeled samples are limited. Although traditional clustering methods can perform unsupervised grouping, they do not account for feature weights46. As a result, when dealing with data containing indicators of varying importance, they may fail to accurately reflect the contribution of each feature. In contrast, weighted clustering algorithms can incorporate feature importance into the clustering process, making them particularly suitable for disaster risk assessment studies. Currently, in risk assessment research, clustering algorithms are typically used to classify disaster occurrence probabilities, calculated by machine learning algorithms, into different clusters, thus delineating study area into varying risk zones47,48. Essentially, this method still relies on machine learning algorithms to predict disaster occurrence probabilities, while clustering algorithms function as a means of probability grading rather than serving as the core risk assessment model. Therefore, this study introduces the concept of weighted clustering algorithms to build a novel risk assessment model.

In summary, current research on using machine learning for corn borer risk assessment remains limited. Moreover, traditional disaster risk assessment methods often rely on manually selected indicators and weights, which may not comprehensively reflect the actual risk49,50. Traditional models are also prone to losing spatial information and struggle to function effectively when historical data are lacking. These limitations constrain their applicability and accuracy29. Therefore, the main objective of this study is to accurately assess the occurrence risk of corn borer disasters in Shandong Province through the optimization of indicators and the construction of risk assessment models. The key contents and contributions of this article are as follows:

We developed a comprehensive indicator system for pests and diseases risk assessment, which lays a solid foundation for future research in this field.

We constructed a feature optimization model specifically designed to address class imbalance, thereby improving the reliability and accuracy of identifying key influencing factors for corn borer risk.

We introduced the concept of weighted clustering to establish a novel corn borer risk assessment framework. This method remains effective even in the absence of historical risk data, representing a methodological innovation in the field.

We revealed the spatial distribution of corn borer disaster risk in Shandong Province, China, from the perspectives of hazard, sensitivity, disaster prevention and mitigation capacity, and comprehensive risk status. The resulting risk zoning maps offer practical guidance for formulating targeted pest control and early warning strategies.

Theories and materials

Regional disaster system and natural disaster risk theories

The theoretical foundation of this study is the regional disaster system theory and natural disaster risk theory, with detailed explanations provided in the supplementary materials. The widely accepted mechanism for natural disaster formation is the four-factor theory17. Therefore, this study integrates the occurrence mechanism of agricultural pests and diseases, drawing on regional disaster system theory and natural disaster risk theory, to conduct risk assessment research from four perspectives: the danger of disaster-causing factors, the sensitivity of the disaster-forming environments, the vulnerability of disaster-bearing objects, and disaster prevention and mitigation capacity.

Study area

Shandong Province, located in the eastern coastal region and the downstream area of the Yellow River in China, boasts a favorable geographical position. It is one of China’s top ten grain-producing provinces and one of the thirteen major grain-producing areas in the country, with an annual planting area of approximately 2.7 × 10⁷ hm² and a corn yield exceeding 20 million tons51. Shandong Province has a warm temperate monsoon climate, with average annual temperatures ranging from 11 °C to 14 °C and annual average precipitation between 550 and 950 millimeters. Approximately 60–70% of the annual precipitation falls during the summer months. With an average of 2290 to 2890 h of sunshine annually, the natural conditions are highly conducive to corn growth52,53. However, due to its favorable climate, Shandong faces a greater threat from the corn borer compared to other provinces with higher corn yields, such as Heilongjiang, Jilin, and Inner Mongolia, which are located further north and have colder climates, making them less affected by corn borer infestations54. The peak oviposition period of corn borer adults typically occurs in June and July, coinciding with the seedling and whorl stages of corn, thus exerting a significant impact on corn quality and yield. Summary of pests and diseases risk assessment indicators

The paper has summarized indicators from relevant assessment systems. Taking into account the biological characteristics of pests and diseases and the mechanisms of disaster occurrence, as well as considering both natural and human-induced factors triggering disasters, we have developed a comprehensive pests and diseases risk assessment indicator system. This system comprises 4 primary indicators, 14 secondary indicators, and 84 tertiary and quaternary indicators. Data collection for this study was conducted based on this system, the detailed contents of which are presented in Table S1 (available in the supplementary materials) .

Data collection

The corn borer, belonging to the Lepidoptera family Crambidae, undergoes approximately 5–6 generations primarily in Shandong Province. It favors moderate temperatures and high humidity, with environmental temperatures between 20 and 26 °C and relative humidity above 80% being most conducive to its growth and development56. The corn borer exhibits strong flight capabilities and phototropism. Newly hatched larvae are agile and drift with the wind to nearby host plants. Mature larvae overwinter as pupae in the stalks, tassels, or roots of host crops such as corn. Upon suitable humidity conditions in the following spring, pupae metamorphose into moths, laying eggs that hatch into larvae, which then infest corn crops57. As indicated above, factors such as precipitation, temperature, sunlight, wind speed, wind direction, and tillage methods may all influence the occurrence of corn borers. Therefore, based on Table S1 and considering the biological characteristics of corn borers, as well as the confidentiality and accessibility of data, this study ultimately collected 43 secondary and tertiary indicator data from four criteria layers: the danger of disaster-causing factors, the sensitivity of disaster-forming environments, the vulnerability of disaster-bearing objects, and disaster prevention and mitigation capacity, for further optimization. These indicators include occurrence data of corn borers, agricultural statistics, socio-economic statistics, and meteorological data from 16 sub-provincial cities in Shandong Province. The data period is from 2007 to 2010 and 2013 to 2019, and the specific indicators and data sources are listed in Table S2 (available in the supplementary materials) .

Data preprocessing

Based on the People’s Republic of China Agricultural Industry Standard—Technical Specification for Forecast Technology of the Corn Borer (NY/T 1611–2008) and the local standard for grading the degree of corn borer occurrence issued by the Shandong Provincial Plant Protection Station, the criteria for grading the degree of corn borer occurrence are shown in Table 1. The corn borer occurrence data were extracted and organized, and the degree was classified according to Table 1. Using a monthly time scale, the frequency of the highest occurrence degree in each city was categorized as light occurrence V1 (levels 0–1 as light occurrence), moderate occurrence V2 (levels 2–3 as moderate occurrence), and severe occurrence V3 (levels 4–5 as severe occurrence). This resulted in the total annual frequency table of corn borer occurrences (Table 2).

Methods

Indicator optimization methods

Feature selection is essential for eliminating redundant or irrelevant variables, reducing model complexity, minimizing the risk of overfitting, and improving both generalization and predictive accuracy. Selecting the most discriminative features with respect to the target variable enhances training efficiency and model interpretability, offering clearer and more reliable support for decision-making. Therefore, we first used Random Forest to eliminate nonlinear redundant features to avoid overfitting, and then applied the Pearson correlation coefficient to assess linear correlations. In cases of significant linear correlation, the feature with the higher importance score was retained, while the lower-scoring feature was removed. This process is illustrated in Fig. 2.

Indicator optimization flowchart.

Pearson correlation coefficient

The Pearson correlation coefficient serves as a simple and rapid method for feature (indicator) optimization, involving the calculation of correlation between each pair of indicators to eliminate irrelevant or redundant features, thereby reducing feature redundancy in input machine learning models58.

Construction of the GA-RF model improved by Borderline-SMOTE

Random Forest (RF)59 is a Bagging ensemble learning algorithm capable of handling high-dimensional data and computing feature importance, making it particularly suitable for feature optimization. Compared to other algorithms, RF has better accuracy and stability, and can evaluate accuracy without the need for a validation set, making it widely used in various disaster risk assessment and warning problems60. Therefore, in this study, the RF model was chosen as the base model for feature optimization research.

However, due to the characteristics of pest and disease outbreaks, the feature optimization dataset for corn borer still suffers from severe class imbalance issues, leading to reduced accuracy in feature optimization. The Borderline-SMOTE algorithm is a data preprocessing method used to address class imbalance problems61. Therefore, to address the issue of imbalanced samples, this study, based on constructing the RF model, utilized the Borderline-SMOTE algorithm to enhance the training set before the Bootstrap Resampling process. This generated more reasonable minority class samples, which were then added to the sample set. Without altering the original data distribution, the sampling subset obtained was a more balanced dataset, effectively improving the robustness of the RF model. Construction of risk assessment model based on weighted K-means clustering algorithm

This paper proposes a risk assessment model, the core idea of which is to use clustering algorithms to divide the disaster occurrence risk in each city into different classes, and classify them into different levels of risk zones based on the characteristics of the classes. The objective of clustering algorithms is to partition the data set into tight and similar clusters, with samples within each cluster being as similar as possible, while samples between different clusters have significant differences. Applied to risk assessment problems, the goal is to construct a sample set based on risk assessment indicators and use clustering algorithms to cluster samples with similar assessment indicators into one cluster, thereby dividing the sample set into different classes to achieve assessment level classification. In risk assessment, the similarity of assessment indicators refers to the proximity of indicator values. In this case, distance-based clustering algorithms are more suitable, and the K-means clustering algorithm is a commonly used distance-based clustering method. However, different indicators have different effects on the correctness of the output results, i.e., they have different weights. Therefore, risk assessment studies should also consider the influence of indicator weights on assessment results. This paper finally introduces the weighted K-means clustering algorithm to construct the risk assessment model. The clustering effect of the weighted K-means clustering algorithm heavily relies on whether an appropriate number of clusters k has been selected. Therefore, before clustering, this paper first determines the optimal number of clusters k through the elbow method66 combined with the silhouette coefficient method67.

The specific steps of the assessment model constructed in this paper are as follows:

Establish an assessment data set based on the constructed risk assessment system. Determine the optimal number of clusters k through the elbow method combined with the silhouette coefficient method;

Use the weighted K-means clustering algorithm to cluster the assessment data set into k different classes;

Use the values of the final clustering centers as data and draw a bar chart of the k clustering centers. By comparing the coordinates of the clustering centers to describe the features of the classes, the risk levels of each class are determined.

Indicator optimization results

Pearson correlation analysis

By computing the correlation coefficient matrix, this study visualized and quantified the relationships between factors. Figure 5 presents the correlation coefficient matrix of all indicators within the study area. The deeper the red color and the smaller the ellipse area, the stronger the positive correlation; the deeper the blue color and the smaller the ellipse area, the stronger the negative correlation. Conversely, lighter colors and larger ellipse areas indicate weaker correlations. The figure shows that there are complex interrelationships among the factors in the study area. Specifically, many factors are interrelated with one another, and each of them also exhibits significant correlations with other variables, demonstrating characteristics of “interaction effects” and “multicollinearity.” When a dataset contains multiple highly correlated features, it increases the risk of model overfitting and reduces model interpretability. Therefore, indicator optimization is necessary68. Given the intricate relationships among variables, correlation coefficients can be used as one method for screening, but they are insufficient for optimal indicator selection on their own. Thus, based on the feature importance derived from the Borderline-SMOTE improved GA-RF model, this study first identified a preliminary set of indicators. Disaster prevention and mitigation capacity: disaster prevention and mitigation capacity is agricultural production and socioeconomic factors that restrict and influence the risk of pests and diseases. The influencing indicators of disaster prevention and mitigation capacity include the total value of agricultural output (Total value of agricultural output: The total monetary value of all products from agriculture, forestry, animal husbandry, and fishery within a region during a specific period), GDP per capita (GDP per capita: The gross domestic product of a region divided by its total population), and effective irrigation area (Effective irrigation area: The area of cultivated land equipped with irrigation systems and capable of being irrigated under normal conditions).

Model accuracy validation

This study adopts a combined strategy of ablation experiments and comparative experiments to comprehensively evaluate the performance of different models under the specific data characteristics of this research. The ablation experiments are employed to assess the precision variations of the RF model before and after improvements. In the comparative experiments, mainstream classifiers such as AdaBoost69 and XGBoost70 are introduced as benchmarks, along with two oversampling techniques (ADASYN and SMOTE-ENN) for performance comparison. The evaluation metrics selected include Accuracy, F1_score, Out-of-Bag (OOB) score, and confusion matrix (Fig. S3).

To enhance the robustness of the results, stratified 5-fold cross-validation is utilized, and the standard deviation and confidence interval of each metric are computed to reflect the stability of model performance.

For models that do not require sample balancing (RF, GA + RF, XGBoost, AdaBoost), stratified 5-fold cross-validation is directly applied to ensure that the class distributions of the training and validation sets in each fold remain consistent with the original dataset. For models requiring sample balancing (SMOTE + RF, SMOTE + GA + RF, ADASYN + GA + RF, SMOTE-ENN + GA + RF, Borderline-SMOTE + GA + RF), stratified 5-fold partitioning is first performed to maintain the class distribution consistency. Oversampling techniques (SMOTE, Borderline-SMOTE, ADASYN, SMOTE-ENN) are then applied exclusively to the training sets, while the validation sets retain the original real data, thereby preventing synthetic samples from leaking into the validation process and avoiding overfitting. Accuracy and F1-score values for each model are calculated based on stratified 5-fold cross-validation.

Since the OOB score is an internal evaluation mechanism specific to the RF model and cannot be obtained through cross-validation, this study calculates the OOB score by averaging the results from five repeated runs. The evaluation metric values for each model are summarized, and the corresponding boxplots are presented as shown in the Fig. 8.

Although models like XGBoost and AdaBoost generally hold potential advantages in many tasks, their performance in this study was limited by the lack of resampling to address data imbalance, which led to a bias toward the majority class and reduced the recognition ability for the minority class, ultimately resulting in lower accuracy.

Discussion

Generalization of the assessment model

The scientificity of the assessment model is the key to this study. In traditional risk assessment studies, when assessing the hazard of two areas, several hazard indicators are usually selected and the weight of the indicators is calculated. Then the weighted comprehensive analysis method is used to calculate the comprehensive assessment value of the two areas, representing the local hazard. The hazard levels are then classified using the natural breaks classification. This method ignores the characteristics of the disaster type to be assessed, so it is unreasonable in some cases. The following takes earthquake disaster as an example to prove the generalization and advantages of the model constructed in this paper.

As shown in Fig. 11A, in the hazard assessment of earthquake disasters, the assessment indicators include earthquake magnitude and frequency. The x-axis represents earthquake magnitude, with a weight of 0.6, while the y-axis represents earthquake frequency, with a weight of 0.4. Suppose area A occurred 8 earthquakes of magnitude 1 during the study period, while area B occurred 2 earthquakes of magnitude 5. By using Formula (4) to calculate the hazard, the hazard index for area A is 8 × 0.4 + 1 × 0.6 = 3.8, and for area B: 2 × 0.4 + 5 × 0.6 = 3.8. This indicates that the earthquake hazard of both areas is the same when using the weighted comprehensive analysis method. However, with each increase in magnitude, the amplitude of the earthquake increases by about 10 times, and the energy of the earthquake increases by about 31.6 times74,75. Therefore, although Region A has more frequent earthquakes, Region B has a higher earthquake energy density and destructiveness, making it more potentially hazardous. This contradicts the conclusion derived from the previous method, confirming that traditional risk assessment models simplify complex evaluation results into a single risk index or level, which leads to the loss of a significant amount of spatial information and details.

Fig. 11

Comparison chart of the evaluation results of the two methods in the hazard assessment of earthquake disasters. (A) is the result of weighted comprehensive analysis method. (B) is the result of our method.

A similar issue is encountered in the assessment of corn borer pest risk levels, where the classification of risk levels does not always correspond directly to actual yield losses. In fact, the yield loss caused by a severe, concentrated outbreak of corn borer is often much greater than the total loss caused by multiple instances of mild or localized pest outbreaks. This is because severe pest damage typically occurs during critical corn growth stages, causing irreversible damage to processes such as pollination and grain filling, while mild pest infestations, even if frequent, allow crops to self-regulate and recover to some extent. Additionally, traditional pest grading methods may focus more on occurrence frequency and coverage area, while overlooking the actual severity of the pest damage and its direct impact on yield, leading to a discrepancy between the risk assessment results and the actual crop losses.

Figure 11B shows the assessment results of the model constructed in this paper. It can be observed that the clustering algorithm separates A and C, B and D, and E into three clusters respectively. Cluster A and C represent areas with low earthquake magnitudes but high frequency, cluster B and D represent areas with low frequency but high earthquake magnitudes, and cluster E represents areas with both low earthquake magnitudes and frequency. Based on the characteristics of these clusters, cluster B and D are classified as high risk areas, cluster A and C as moderate risk areas, and cluster E as a low risk area. It can be seen that the approach adopted in this study clusters samples with similar indicator values into the same class, fully considering the spatial location information of different assessment indicators of the samples, thereby avoiding the problem of losing a significant amount of spatial information in the weighted comprehensive analysis method. The model is more reasonable and applicable to a wider range of scenarios, with stronger generalization. Moreover, the weighted K-means clustering algorithm also considers the influence of indicator weights on the clustering results, making the assessment results more accurate and mitigating the deficiencies of mathematical-statistical models to the greatest extent.

Reliability of clustering algorithm

The core concept of the risk assessment model developed in this study is to categorize the disaster occurrence risks of various cities into different clusters using clustering algorithms, and to classify these clusters into different risk levels based on their characteristics. A weighted K-means algorithm was employed as the primary clustering method, considering the influence of indicator weights on the assessment results. However, under the same weighting conditions, it is still necessary to compare this method with other clustering algorithms to identify the optimal approach. Therefore, we selected the weighted agglomerative hierarchical clustering (weighted AHC) and weighted DBSCAN algorithms for comparison with the weighted K-means algorithm. The number of clusters in weighted AHC was set to be consistent with that of weighted K-means, using the “average” linkage method. For weighted DBSCAN, the min_samples parameter was set to 1, and all distance computations were performed using the weighted Euclidean distance, with other parameters kept at their default values. The clustering performance was evaluated using Silhouette Coefficient, Calinski–Harabasz Index, and Davies–Bouldin Index. The experimental results are shown in the Table 5.
