After determining the selected model, the performance of machine learning models still relies on the tuning of hyperparameters38, 39–40. Similarly, in the weighted K-means clustering algorithm, the number of clusters (k-value) directly determines both the quantity and quality of the resulting clusters, which has a direct impact on the risk zoning outcomes. An inappropriate k-value may lead to overfitting or underfitting, thereby affecting the clustering quality. Therefore, this study employs the Elbow Method, Silhouette Score, and Davies-Bouldin Index to jointly determine the optimal k-value, as shown in Fig. 12.

First, the hazard assessment datasets were input into the three methods respectively, and the evaluation metrics under different k values (k = 1 ~ 10) were calculated. The results are shown in Fig. 12a. From the SSE curve, it can be seen that the error decreases rapidly before k = 4 and the decline slows when k ≥ 4, indicating that k = 4 is the “elbow point.” At this point, the silhouette coefficient reaches a local maximum and the Davies-Bouldin index is minimized, suggesting that the clustering performance is optimal when k = 4. Therefore, the optimal number of clusters for hazard assessment is k = 4. Figure 12b shows the trend of K values for sensitivity assessment. The SSE curve declines significantly before k = 4 and flattens when k ≥ 7. Considering that the silhouette coefficient reaches its maximum and the Davies-Bouldin index is minimized at k = 4, it can be concluded that k = 4 is also the optimal number of clusters for sensitivity assessment. Figure 12c presents the clustering results for disaster prevention and mitigation capacity. The SSE curve shows the greatest variation between k = 4 and k = 6. Although the silhouette coefficient is highest at k = 2, such a small number of clusters is not practical. Taking into account the second-highest silhouette coefficient at k = 5 and the lowest Davies-Bouldin index, k = 5 is ultimately selected as the optimal number of clusters for disaster prevention and mitigation capacity. Figure 12d shows the results of the comprehensive risk assessment. The SSE curve has a clear inflection between k = 4 and k = 5. At k = 4, the silhouette coefficient is the highest and the Davies-Bouldin index is the lowest, indicating that the clustering performance is optimal. Therefore, the optimal number of clusters for comprehensive risk assessment is determined to be k = 4.

Reliability of zoning results

The data used in this study covers the years 2007–2010 and 2013–2019. To validate the reliability of the zoning results, relevant information from 2020 and beyond was consulted. According to the “Pest and Disease Information” released by the Agricultural and Rural Affairs Bureau of Heze City in 2020 (http://hznync.heze.gov.cn), the average number of live pests detected per hundred corn plants through stem stripping was 42.3, an increase of 16% compared to the same period last year. The occurrence level of corn borers was classified as level 4, indicating a severe occurrence. Additionally, the forecast results from 2021 to 2023 also indicate severe occurrences. These findings are consistent with the assessment results of this study, verifying the reliability of the results obtained in this paper.

Limitations and broader implications of our work

Although the model proposed in this paper addresses several limitations of traditional risk assessment approaches, it also introduces new complexities and challenges. In contrast to conventional supervised prediction models that require extensive labeled datasets, our unsupervised clustering-based risk assessment framework proves especially advantageous in data-limited settings. This is particularly relevant in many regions where long-term pest monitoring data are unavailable, but meteorological, agronomic, and socio-economic indicators can be accessed. This study therefore provides a practical solution for real-time risk assessment and spatial planning.

Moreover, the spatial heterogeneity of corn borer risk revealed in our model aligns with biological findings regarding the pest’s temperature and humidity preferences. For instance, regions such as Heze and Dezhou are characterized by warm, humid conditions and dense crop residues—ideal for overwintering and reemergence of corn borers. This supports previous ecological studies showing that corn borer population dynamics are heavily influenced by microclimatic and agronomic factors. By incorporating indicator weighting and spatial structure into the clustering process, our model avoids the shortcomings of traditional risk scoring methods—namely, the oversimplification of diverse risk factors into a single composite index. This methodological innovation enables more interpretable and context-sensitive results, which can inform precision agriculture practices and policy design. From a methodological perspective, the framework can be extended to other agricultural pest or disease scenarios, especially when comprehensive risk assessment is needed without high-quality occurrence labels. Future work can explore integration with remote sensing data or real-time surveillance platforms to further enhance prediction and response capabilities.

However, the integration of multiple machine learning components inevitably increases the computational complexity of the model. To address the prevalent issue of class imbalance in pest datasets, we constructed a feature optimization model using Borderline-SMOTE to improve GA-RF, combined with Pearson correlation analysis to identify key influencing indicators. Subsequently, to overcome spatial information loss in traditional models, we introduced a weighted clustering algorithm to assess spatial risk levels. While this multi-step structure enhances accuracy and generalizability, it also leads to increased computational demands, particularly during large-scale applications. Algorithms such as Borderline-SMOTE, genetic algorithms, and random forests are computationally intensive, especially with high-dimensional data. In addition, the time complexity of K-means clustering rises significantly with increased data volume and the number of clusters, adding further computational burden. Compared to traditional weighted index approaches, the proposed method requires significantly more resources, potentially reducing practical efficiency when scaling up.

To mitigate these scalability challenges, particularly for national or continental applications, leveraging distributed computing architectures is a crucial next step. Cloud computing platforms, such as Google Earth Engine (GEE), are exceptionally well-suited for this purpose. GEE’s parallel processing capabilities, combined with its vast, readily accessible archive of global meteorological and remote sensing data, would not only drastically reduce the computational burden of our framework but also streamline the data acquisition process. By porting our model to such a platform, the intensive tasks of feature optimization and clustering on massive datasets become feasible, paving the way for large-scale, near-real-time risk assessment and monitoring.

Furthermore, while the cloud model method used for determining feature weights reduces subjectivity compared to direct expert scoring or AHP, it still relies on expert input to a certain degree. This introduces potential subjective bias in the weighting process. In future research, combining objective data-driven weight determination (e.g., entropy weighting, machine learning-based importance scoring) with expert knowledge may enhance the robustness and credibility of the risk assessment framework.

In summary, while our proposed method offers strong advantages in flexibility, interpretability, and biological relevance, there remains room for further improvement in computational efficiency, scalability, and weight objectivity, which we aim to address in future studies.

Conclusion

Against the backdrop of global food security being heavily impacted by crop pests, this study focused on corn borer and constructed a novel method for assessing and zoning corn borer disaster risks. Firstly, the Borderline-SMOTE enhanced GA-RF model and the Pearson correlation coefficient were jointly utilized to optimize the feature subset of corn borer disasters. Subsequently, considering the influence of both spatial location and weight of indicators on the assessment results, a risk assessment model based on weighted K-means clustering algorithm was proposed. Finally, combined with the theory of natural disaster risk, the spatial zoning of corn borer occurrence risk was realized by taking Shandong Province of China as the study area. The following valuable conclusions can be drawn:

The Borderline-SMOTE-GA-RF feature optimization model constructed in this study effectively addressed the problem of class imbalance in the corn borer sample set. Compared to the original RF model, the OOB_Score, Accuracy, and F1_Score improved by 18.64, 11.12, and 11.21% respectively, outperforming typical machine learning algorithms such as AdaBoost and XGBoost. Based on a large collection of indicator information, this model combined with the Pearson correlation coefficient, optimized 17 indicators under 3 criterion layers, establishing a corn borer risk assessment system in Shandong Province.

Compared with the classical weighted comprehensive analysis method, the weighted K-means risk assessment model constructed in this paper fully considers the spatial location information of assessment indicators and has better generalization. Taking the Shandong Province of China as the study area, the risk zoning of the corn borer disaster was realized by combining cloud model and risk assessment system. The results show that Heze, Dezhou, and Weihai City are high risk areas. In comparison, the risk of corn borer disasters occurring is higher in the southwestern and northern areas of Shandong Province, while the risk in the central and eastern areas of Shandong Province is lower. This conclusion is consistent with some publicly available data, indicating the reliability of the results.

This paper proposes a new risk assessment model based on the weighted K-means clustering algorithm, providing new insights for agricultural disaster zoning research. Meanwhile, this study is the first to establish a corn borer risk assessment system based on improved machine learning methods. The proposed model enables rapid and cost-effective delineation of corn borer risk zones, providing insights into the spatial distribution of risk levels and identifying high-risk areas for corn borer outbreaks in Shandong Province. This facilitates precise prevention and control in key regions. Moreover, the quantified importance of various driving factors influencing corn borer risks offers valuable references for future research by other scholars. Due to the difficulty in obtaining data, the assessment and zoning results of this study are at the sub-provincial city level, which is still not detailed enough. In future research, higher-resolution zoning will be achieved by combining small-scale data to assist relevant units in making more detailed decisions.

2024 DEC 20 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Research findings on environment are discussed in a new report. According to news originating from Braga, Portugal, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "The main purpose of this study was the development of a methodology to assess the potential impacts of forest fires on geoheritage through a systematic and practical approach. The proposed methodology was applied to the geoheritage of the Estrela UNESCO Global Geopark (UGGp) in Portugal, following a forest fire in August 2022 that affected approximately 15% of its geosites (22 out of 147)."


Funders for this research include Erasmus+; European Commission; Foundation For Science And Technology.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Institute of Earth Sciences: "A total of 20 geosites were selected for analysis, including eight directly impacted by the fire and 12 that remained unaffected. The assessment framework integrates vulnerability and hazard factors. Vulnerability was quantified based on two primary criteria: geosites value and their educational and touristic uses. Each criterion was operationalized through defined parameters and indicators, supported by standardized guidelines for evaluation. Forest fire hazard data were obtained from the Portuguese Institute for the Conservation of Nature and Forests (ICNF). The degradation risk was calculated as a function of these two factors. The results indicate that the highest vulnerability level identified was 'low,' signifying the absence of substantial loss in scientific value. However, discernible impacts on cultural, scenic and ecological values, and on educational/touristic uses were observed across most geosites. The maximum degradation risk was classified as 'medium,' suggesting that the predominant granite and glacial landforms within the study area exhibit a relatively high degree of resilience to forest fire-induced damage."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The findings underscore the importance of implementing targeted management strategies to mitigate the impacts of forest fires within the Estrela UGGp. Moreover, the methodology offers a transferable framework for geoheritage degradation risk assessment, which could be applied in diverse contexts to further enhance the understanding and conservation of geoheritage."
For more information on this research see: Assessment of forest fires impacts on geoheritage: A study in the Estrela UNESCO Global Geopark, Portugal. Hurricane debris fuels fires: Firefighters in North and South Carolina were battling multiple wind-driven wildfires Monday in rugged terrain that complicated containment efforts, officials said. Millions of trees knocked down by Hurricane Helene last year combined with long stretches of dry weather this spring are making for a long and active fire season in the Carolinas, North Carolina State University forestry and environmental resources professor Robert Scheller said. "Helene just dropped tons of fuel on the ground," Scheller said. "Then these flash droughts allow that fuel to dry out very fast."

Both South Carolina and North Carolina have issued statewide bans on outdoor burning. North Carolina fires Mandatory evacuations continue for about 165 properties in parts of Polk County in western North Carolina, about 80 miles (129 kilometers) west of Charlotte, according to county spokesperson Kellie Cannon. Three fires burned at least 7.5 square miles (19.5 square kilometers) in the county and the two larger blazes were completely uncontained, Cannon said in a social media update Monday morning. The Black Cove Fire, one of the larger ones, was moving toward neighboring Henderson County, Cannon said. Kim Callaway, who lives near one of the evacuated areas in Polk County, has prepared her home, WLOS-TV reported. "We've already actually evacuated everything that we thought that was important," Callaway said. "And now we're just staying at the house and trying to do what we can to get our house prepared if the firemen need to show up and hold the line." A downed power line sparked the Black Cove Fire, but the causes of the other two fires in Polk County were under investigation, according to North Carolina Forest Service spokesperson Jeremy Waldrop. A number of other wildfires burning across the state including one that damaged 500 vehicles at a salvage yard in Burke County, officials said. South Carolina fires Two fires in the South Carolina mountains have led Gov. Henry McMaster to declare a state of emergency. One fire was in Table Rock State Park in Pickens County and the other was on Persimmon Ridge in Greenville County. Winds and difficult mountainous terrain allowed blazes to grow, the South Carolina Forestry Commission said. The Table Rock Fire expanded to more than 2 square miles (5.3 square kilometers), including several hundred acres that firefighters intentionally burned to try to contain the flames, officials said. The Persimmon Ridge Fire, which started Saturday, spread to more than 1.25 square miles (3.2 square kilometers) despite many dozens of water drops, the commission said. Human activity ignited both the Table Rock and Persimmon Ridge fires. No injuries had been reported, and while no structures were imminently threatened, voluntary evacuations of about 100 homes remained in place. How a September hurricane is creating March fires Scheller, the North Carolina State University professor, predicted this busy fire season if the region saw dry weather following Helene. Scientists saw something similar in 2022 when a fire burned more than 51 square miles (133 square kilometers) of timberland in the Florida Panhandle. The Bertha Swamp Road Fire almost directly followed the eye pattern from 2018's Hurricane Michael and the fallen pine trees left behind. Pines and their waxy needles dry out and become very flammable, Scheller said. The fallen trunks can also block roads and paths used to fight fires, experts said. The last ingredient to fuel wildfires is dry weather. Despite recent rain, the Carolinas are undergoing an extreme drought, according to federal monitors. The common denominator for many fires on the East Coast is human activity, whether people burn debris, light a campfire that isn't well watched or toss out cigarette, Scheller said. And more people living next to areas that can burn make fires a bigger threat, he said. New Jersey fire A forest fire burning in New Jersey's million-acre Pinelands region was 100% contained on Monday morning, the New Jersey Forest Fire Services said in a post on X. The fire was first spotted Saturday and burned through about 3.5 square miles (5.8 kilometers). That blaze led authorities to evacuate two campgrounds in Wharton State Forest, officials said. The cause was under investigation. Fire forecast A front moving off the East Coast brought rain and more humidity to the area, helping firefighters Monday. But not much rain fell and temperatures are expected to get warmer and the air drier as the week goes on, likely meaning another round of wildfires unless people follow burn bans and fire safety. "It is absolutely paramount that folks respect the statewide ban on all open burning," North Carolina Forest Service spokesperson Philip Jackson. said.

urn:contentItem:6G2H-WG53-RRMS-P48V-00000-00FIGHTING FIRE WITH RESEARCH: HOW A SCIENTIST IS PROTECTING PEOPLE AND PROPERTY FROM WILDFIRES2025-06-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:07:19ZLexisNexisFIGHTING FIRE WITH RESEARCH: HOW A SCIENTIST IS PROTECTING PEOPLE AND PROPERTY FROM WILDFIRESStates News ServiceGAITHERSBURG, MD

The following information was released by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST):

By: Brian Gutierrez

Fire protection engineer Alex Maranghides is a longtime leader in the WUI fire research group at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). He and his team have investigated some of the most devastating wildfire disasters of the last 20 years, from the Waldo Canyon Fire in Colorado to the Camp Fire, which destroyed Paradise, California. Alex and his team used these investigations to learn about how fire moves through a community, find vulnerabilities and evaluate evacuation procedures. Using these investigations, as well as controlled laboratory experiments, Alex led the effort to create practical guidance for saving lives during fires.

In recognition of his impact, Alex has been named an honoree of the Samuel J. Heyman Service to America Medal, which recognizes exceptional government employees. The award, commonly known as the Sammies and often called the Oscars of public service, is presented by the Partnership for Public Service.

To celebrate, we caught up with Alex to ask a few questions about his career and some of the most impactful findings from his wildfire research.

What does a fire protection engineer do?

Fire protection engineering is only about 100 years old. The field has two primary goals: enhancing life safety and reducing property losses from fire.

Historically, the profession has focused on fire inside buildings. But the problem of outdoor fires is escalating rapidly. Wildfires are becoming larger and more intense, so they have a larger impact on life safety and infrastructure.

What's behind this increase in wildfire danger?

There are a few reasons. Occasional small fires are healthy. They clear out the dry leaves and dead wood. But for over three-quarters of a century in the U.S., we tended to put out all forest fires early. That policy resulted in an extensive buildup of material ready to burn. And that, together with droughts and other environmental conditions, is now creating explosive fire behavior.

But that's not the whole story. We're also building more homes in and near forested areas. These areas are called the wildland urban interface (WUI). And they are our main concern.

How has wildfire research changed during your career?

As wildfires have gotten larger, we've needed to change our approach from actively fighting the fire to reducing the hazards ahead of time and having an evacuation plan.

When the town of Paradise, California, was hit by a fire in 2018, 20,000 structures were exposed at the same time. There aren't 20,000 fire engines in the entire state of California. Actively fighting a fire that large is unrealistic.

How is fire different from other types of natural disasters, such as earthquakes or hurricanes?

Most of my work has been about studying fires after they happened. We want to know what went wrong and find the success stories, so we can learn from these tragedies and avoid repeating mistakes.

There are a few unique challenges to investigating fires compared to other natural disasters. For one thing, fire makes more fire. Other disasters don't self-propagate. Hurricanes don't make more hurricanes; tornadoes don't make tornadoes.

Another challenge is that firefighters save structures during the event. That makes it really hard to know: Did a home survive because of the way it was built, or did it survive because it was defended by a firefighter?

A third fundamental difference is that the exposures are extremely local. The heat in one spot could easily be one hundred times higher than a spot just five feet away. That's really different from, say, an earthquake, where all the buildings are struck in more or less the same way.

What matters when it comes to protecting your home against wildfires?

You and your neighbors have to deal with two fundamental challenges: embers and flames.

Embers can be a problem as they can cause ignitions inside or outside of a structure. Embers can be very small or larger than the size of my fist. During a severe wildfire, your home may be bombarded by literally a million embers, so it's important to seal off your home to prevent them from getting inside. One example is the garage door trim. If the trim doesn't connect with the floor, embers go right in that little gap, start a fire in the garage, and burn your house down.

We have identified more than 40 similar potential ember vulnerabilities for houses. You have to deal with all of them. With that many embers, they're going to find that weak spot.

The second part is the flames. The most effective way to prevent flames from spreading is to get rid of the fuel and remove that exposure. For a fire protection engineer, anything that can burn is considered fuel. Removing a fuel is straightforward, but relocating it can be tricky. Some fuel, like sheds, RVs, boats and wood piles, are easily movable. These items should be moved further away from homes. Distance is the most effective way to prevent fire from spreading. What we absolutely do not want is residents moving fuels away from their own homes and placing them near their neighbors' houses. This is a very common scenario in high-density construction. When this happens, we are solving one problem but creating another.

Other fuels, like your neighbor's house, are immovable. That's when it's important to use "fire hardening." That involves steps like installing fire-resistant siding and windows.

But this has to be done at the community level. If you do all the preparations on your parcel and your neighbor does nothing, and your homes are less than 25 feet apart, you're going to be very lucky if your house survives.

What are some of the key things you've learned about wildfire evacuation and sheltering?

After someone reports a forest fire to 9-1-1, it could easily take two hours to fully evacuate a small town. That means if the fire can get to the community in less than two hours, you will not have enough time to get the people out. In that scenario, ordering an evacuation can be very dangerous. When cars are stuck in traffic trying to escape, those cars can be overrun by fire, causing fatalities.

We recently updated a report called ESCAPE that helps the decision makers fire chiefs, city officials and law enforcement plan for these no-notice or limited-notice fires. The report helps you figure out if you're going to have enough time to evacuate your community. It also helps you plan for what to do when there isn't time for a full evacuation. In those cases, we want to bring people to open spaces nearby such as golf courses or big parking lots to serve as Temporary Fire Refuge Areas. These areas don't guarantee safety, but it's better to be in an open space than to be trapped in your car or home.

The key idea behind ESCAPE is to be ready ahead of time. If you're not prepared, it will be very dangerous. You have to do the training, educate the public, work with mutual aid, label the Temporary Fire Refuge Areas, do drills, collect the information and work with your other jurisdictions so that it's all connected. It's impossible to do all this work when a fire is approaching.

It seems like a critical part of your work is not only doing the research, but also telling local fire officials and the public about it. How do you balance those two responsibilities?

If we do research and file it away, it doesn't do anything. It is absolutely critical to make sure that we translate the science into readily understandable material. For example, our full report on the Camp Fire is 1,000 pages long to date. To make it easier to use, we distilled our advice for evacuation and shelter into a 169-page report, which can teach people the core ideas, and they can refer back to the longer documents to learn more. That was still a little too much, so we simplified that further into a free online training tool that can teach you the core ideas in three hours.

It's up to us to make sure that the science is usable, and we're always searching for ways to make our findings more accessible.

You've been studying wildfires for more than 20 years. What has driven you to work so hard at this problem for decades?

It's not an easy thing to witness a destroyed community. When I go out and see the devastation, and I know I can do something about it, that's the incentive for me to do the work that I do.

There's a great opportunity here at NIST, not just to do science but to have an impact on people's lives.

Is there any advice you have for young people who are thinking about going into wildfire research?

I think this is the largest fire problem for the next generation. There is at least a generation if not two worth of high impact work to be done here.

Wildfire used to be a problem only for Western states. It's no longer a Western problem. This year, we've had fires in South Carolina all the way to north of Boston, and in some cases, 100 fires at once. The bad news is that the East is even less prepared; they don't have the infrastructure, the experience or the building codes. The good news is that we can leverage the knowledge from previous fires to prepare.

What has been the biggest factor in completing this important work?

We had the help of many, many people who made this research possible. Over the years, we have had hundreds and hundreds of external collaborations that have helped us re-create these catastrophic events so that we can learn from them. We've also had a lot of support internally at NIST to create our wildfire research group and create high-impact case studies, laboratory experiments, reports and online tools. It has really been a team effort.

urn:contentItem:6GG5-VWR3-RRJX-N1D5-00000-00DSRR model for safety vulnerability assessment of power grid infrastructure in Henan Province China2025-11-15T08:07:19Z2025-11-15T08:07:19ZLexisNexisDSRR model for safety vulnerability assessment of power grid infrastructure in Henan Province China

Supplementary InformationThe online version contains supplementary material available at https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-025-07805-w.Publisher’s noteSpringer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Abstract

Weak links in modern power grids can lead to cascading failures from isolated incidents, making the scientific assessment of grid and transmission line vulnerability essential for preventing large-scale blackouts. This study conceptualizes transmission lines as functionally critical infrastructure and develops a four-dimensional vulnerability assessment framework encompassing Danger, Susceptibility, Resistance, and Recoverability, taking into account natural environmental conditions, human disturbances, grid operational states, and emergency response capabilities. Distinct from conventional classification methods that primarily rely on structural topology or subjective judgment, this study adopts a hazard index–based approach and introduces an objective weighting mechanism using the entropy method to quantitatively evaluate and classify indicators across the four dimensions. A case study of 500 kV transmission lines in Henan Province, China, reveals that the composite vulnerability index of the province’s critical power infrastructure reaches 57.2, indicating a high level of vulnerability. Among the transmission towers, 19.8% are classified at the “Higher” level and 40.6% at the “High” level. Considerable variation in Recoverability among towers significantly influences the overall vulnerability assessment results. Moreover, the distribution of susceptibility to various hazards and accidents shows strong spatial and temporal heterogeneity, closely related to seasonal factors and tower locations. Based on these findings, targeted strategies are proposed from the perspectives of line inspection and differentiated management, providing technical support for enhancing power grid resilience and improving disaster response efficiency.

IntroductionAlthough the large-scale interconnection of power grids has achieved a wider range of optimal resource allocation, it has also reduced the safety and stability of the system, with widespread power outages caused by localized failures occurring multiple times1,2. In recent years, earthquakes, rain, snow, freezing weather, rainstorms, typhoons, and other natural disasters around the world, as well as intentional or unintentional external damage are threatening the stable operation of power grid transmission lines, even leading to large-scale power outages and other accidents, causing serious economic losses and social impact. For example, on July 13, 2019, a transformer fire caused a massive power outage in Midtown and the Upper West Side of Manhattan in New York City, U.S., with nearly 70,000 customers affected; the destruction of critical infrastructure and power disruptions in Ya’an, Sichuan, China in 2013 and Wenchuan, Sichuan, China in 2008 due to earthquakes, and the massive power outage in southern China in 2008 due to severe weather caused by freezing rain and snow. In a comprehensive analysis of the above power emergencies, the initial cause is mostly the damage to the grid system by external factors, which leads to the unstable operation of the grid and thus causes serious socio-economic losses3, 4–5. Therefore, it is crucial to design a comprehensive vulnerability assessment method to evaluate the safety risks of the grid in the context of natural disasters and external damage, and to develop targeted vulnerability reduction measures for the assessment results.

The vulnerability analysis of the grid was first proposed by Petroianu et al. in 1974, but due to the small scale of the grid at that time, the vulnerability analysis of the grid did not receive sufficient attention. With the increasing scale and complexity of power grids, the consequences of power grid accidents have become more and more serious, and the vulnerability of power grids in their own structure and operation state has drawn people’s attention again, A. A Found reintroduced the concept of vulnerability in 1994, used the transient energy function to analyze the vulnerability of power grids, and made it a new element of power system dynamic safety assessment6. Subsequently, scholars worldwide initiated research on vulnerability assessment in the power sector. Some researchers proposed a vulnerability assessment method based on cascading indices and spectral graph metrics, which involves calculating and comparing these indices to rank transmission lines under different contingency scenarios7,8.

According to the different research contents, the research on vulnerability in the field of electric power can be divided into three categories.

(1) Technical vulnerability assessment: Also known as electrical vulnerability, this method analyzes the power system’s structure and operational mode9 based on the grid’s topology and system operating conditions. Depending on the research perspective, technical vulnerability in power grids can be classified into structural vulnerability10, state vulnerability, and a comprehensive vulnerability assessment that integrates both perspectives11, 12–13.

Grid structural vulnerability assessment focuses on the tendency of a grid system to fail to maintain its topological integrity and normal operation after a certain unit or units exit due to external disturbances or failures in the system, and analyzes grid resilience from the perspective of the importance of a node or branch in the grid structure. For a particular grid, its network structure is unique, and therefore, structural vulnerability is a reflection of the inherent vulnerability of the grid14,15. Complex network-based research methods are the mainstream approach to assessing the structural vulnerability of the grid16,17. The grid state vulnerability assessment focuses on the tendency of the electrical parameters showing the system operating state to change abnormally and approach a critical value when a fault occurs in the system, thus making the grid unable to continue to provide services, and analyzing the grid’s ability to resist faults and disturbances from the operating state5. With the in-depth study of grid vulnerability, some scholars believe that the analysis model considering only structural vulnerability ignores the state parameters in operation, and the analysis method considering only state vulnerability ignores the importance of the unit in the grid structure, and both analysis and assessment methods have certain shortcomings18,19. The assessment methods of grid vulnerability gradually develop from single attribute vulnerability assessment to integrated vulnerability assessment combining structural vulnerability and state vulnerability20, 21, 22–23.

(2) Physical Vulnerability Assessment: For components or infrastructure in the grid, the risk of accidents such as insulation degradation, transmission line, and facility damage due to external influences (natural disasters, climatic factors, human damage) is analyzed for these elements8,24. The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) jointly developed the VRAP (Vulnerability Risk Analysis Program) in 1997, which is an early application of physical vulnerability assessment for power facilities. The practicality of vulnerability assessment was subsequently optimized in 2002 with the promulgation of the Draft Methodology for Vulnerability Assessment of Power System Infrastructure. Since then, scholars have begun to focus on such assessment methods, Kang L et al. analyzed the vulnerability of grid infrastructure when it is affected by external factors through a risk assessment approach, and proposed a model of joint cooperation between enterprises and the government to assess25. Baiardi F et al. used hierarchical analysis to assess the vulnerability of critical infrastructures in the event of an attack using power equipment as an example26. Wang Yujie et al. used simulation modeling to assess the physical vulnerability of the Yunnan power grid by focusing on the impact of geological disasters on power grid towers27.

(3) Emergency system vulnerability: Analyze the response and recovery capacity of the power emergency management system in the face of accident hazards. At present, there are few studies on emergency vulnerability in the field of electric power, and most of the existing studies are conducted from two aspects: vulnerability of the emergency system and vulnerability of emergency capability. Cheng Zhengang et al. constructed an assessment index of the vulnerability of the electric power emergency system from nine aspects, including the legal basis and organizational structure28. Zhu Weidong constructed an evaluation index system for the vulnerability of emergency management capability of nuclear power plant safety accidents from the attack-defense perspective29.

In summary, compared with existing studies, this paper takes into account the grid’s ability to resist disturbances and recover from disasters while considering the degree of disturbances and impacts on the grid from a safety risk perspective, and analyzes the grid and its line vulnerability qualitatively and quantitatively using the entropy weight method and the hazard index method, which qualitatively indicates the assignment criteria and vulnerability level levels of each index, and quantitatively is a method of obtaining and analyzing safety vulnerability evaluation data using GIS software, which is combined with the entropy weight method to calculate the grid safety vulnerability level. A 500 kV transmission line in Henan Province was selected for case study, and from the perspective of line operation and inspection and emergency repair, targeted countermeasure suggestions were given for different safety vulnerability characteristics and levels, with better identification capability and higher identification accuracy for transmission towers and line vulnerability levels, providing a more accurate basis for the development and implementation of measures to ensure grid operation and reduce grid vulnerability.

To achieve a scientifically sound assessment of power grid security vulnerability, this study designs the research process as illustrated in Fig. 1, following the logical sequence outlined below: First, based on the theory of system vulnerability, the study defines a four-dimensional framework—Danger, Susceptibility, Resistance, and Recoverability—to establish the theoretical foundation. Second, an evaluation index system is constructed to ensure that the four dimensions are measurable and comparable. Third, the hazard index method is applied to assign values to the indicators, and the entropy weight method is employed to determine the weights, thereby enhancing objectivity and comparability among the indicators. Fourth, the DSRR comprehensive vulnerability assessment model is developed to map the indicators to a composite index. Finally, an empirical case study is conducted on the 500 kV transmission lines in Henan Province to test the model’s applicability and assess indicator variability. Each phase builds on the previous one in a logically progressive manner, from theoretical construction to empirical analysis, forming a complete and coherent cycle that ensures the vulnerability assessment results are both theoretically grounded and practically valid.Fig. 1

Technical roadmap for grid safety vulnerability assessment.

Method

Entropy method

The entropy method determines the weights based on the information utility value of each index. The concept of entropy originates from physics and represents the degree of disorder of the system, and it is believed in information theory that the higher the entropy of information, the lower its usable value30. The weights derived using the entropy method reflect the extent to which a given factor contributes to variations among different evaluation targets. For example, when the transmission line spans a small area, the climatic conditions are nearly identical, resulting in minimal differences in their impact on various transmission towers. However, even within a small area, road traffic conditions can vary significantly, leading to notable differences in their influence on transmission towers. Consequently, when applying the entropy method, the weight of road traffic factors will far exceed that of climatic conditions.

The entropy method plays a pivotal role in the assessment of power grid safety vulnerability, particularly in its ability to achieve objective weighting, quantify indicator differentiation, and integrate the influence of multiple factors. By calculating the information entropy of each indicator, it determines weights scientifically, avoids subjective biases, emphasizes the impact of key indicators, and downplays less critical factors, thereby constructing a comprehensive vulnerability index. Moreover, the entropy method dynamically captures the spatial and temporal variations in vulnerability, providing robust data support for the assessment results. This approach facilitates the identification of highly vulnerable regions and components, offering a reliable foundation for optimizing power grid layout, designing protective strategies, and ensuring efficient resource allocation31. Thus, the vulnerability results calculated using the entropy method effectively reflect the relative vulnerability levels among different objects within the study system. Hazard index method

The hazard index method is an evaluation method proposed by Dow Chemical Company in 1964 for quantitative evaluation of fire and explosion risks, and can also be used to evaluate the hazards of potentially hazardous installations such as power distribution and drainage systems, in addition to the fire and explosion field32. This method assigns values to indicators by grading the status of stored material types, safety devices and measures to obtain scores for the corresponding indices, so that data of different orders of magnitude can be graded and then assigned to achieve a dimensionless processing of indicators.

To achieve dimensionless processing of different indicators, the hazard index method mainly adopts two types of scoring approaches: (1) linear normalization, which is suitable for continuous variables, and (2) graded assignment, which is suitable for discrete variables with national standards or empirical classification criteria.

For continuous variables, the scoring formula is expressed as:7where is the hazard index score of the -th evaluation object for the -th indicator, is the raw data value, and and are the reference maximum and minimum values of the indicator. and represent the upper and lower bounds of the score, which are uniformly set to 100 and 10 in this study to ensure consistency across indicators. For indicators with clearly defined grading standards (such as tower-to-road distance, soil pH value, air quality index, etc.), a stepwise assignment method is adopted. Based on relevant standards or literature, interval thresholds are defined and fixed scores are assigned accordingly.

Due to the different units of the evaluation indicators, it is necessary to perform dimensionless processing before calculation. In this paper, the hazard index method is used for dimensionless treatment of each indicator. The raw data of the indicators in this paper differ greatly in magnitude; for example, the raw data of the distance indicator ranges from tens to thousands of meters, while the temperature indicator is nearly within the same order of magnitude. If the range method were used, the dispersion degree of the distance index would be much larger than that of the temperature index, leading to the failure of the temperature index in the evaluation. Therefore, compared to the range method, the hazard index method is more suitable for this paper.

Power grid safety vulnerability assessment model

Construction of evaluation index system

McEntire (2001) states that vulnerability is determined by the extent to which the components of a disaster include risk, susceptibility, resistance, and recoverability. Risk and susceptibility are summarised as adverse factors, while resistance and recoverability are summarised as capacity factors33,34. The current research on vulnerability in the field of electric power is divided into technical vulnerability, physical vulnerability and emergency vulnerability. To differentiate from technical vulnerability, this paper defines grid safety vulnerability as "the degree to which transmission lines (including towers) are vulnerable to loss of power system functions and adverse impacts on society due to insufficient structural strength or emergency recovery capabilities in the face of natural disasters and human damage”. This concept emphasizes the outstanding characteristics of four aspects of the safety vulnerability of power grid: (1) Danger: the possibility and severity of damage to the physical structure of power grid caused by natural disasters and man-made damage; (2) Susceptibility: the scope and degree of influence after the occurrence of power grid accident; (3) Resistance: the resistance of internal factors such as the structural strength of the power grid and the current operating state to external influences; (4) recoverability: the emergency repair and recovery ability of the power grid. Selecting the index elements according to the four aspects of “danger”, “susceptibility”, “resistance” and “recoverability” is the key to building the evaluation index system using the safety vulnerability model. Thus, we call it the DSRR model, which systematically reflects an analytical view of the relationship between environmental and human systems. The indicators in these four aspects each influence the grid’s safety vulnerability from the perspectives of both “offense” and “defense”. Specifically, danger and susceptibility are the attack factors of vulnerability and have a positive correlation with the safety vulnerability of the power grid. Danger represents the extent to which the power grid is affected by natural disasters and other external factors. Susceptibility represents the impact of the accident on society. The deeper the impact of the accident, the larger the scope of impact, the lower the social acceptance. It can be inferred that the higher the danger and susceptibility, the higher the safety vulnerability of the power grid. Resistance and recoverability are the defense factors of vulnerability and are negatively related to the safety vulnerability of the power grid. Resistance represents the ability of the transmission line itself to resist external influences, and recoverability represents the ability of emergency repair and recovery after the power grid accident. The higher the resistance and recoverability, the lower the vulnerability. The relationship between them is shown in Fig. 2.Fig. 2

Results and discussion of power grid safety vulnerability assessment

The results extracted using the aforementioned software can be assigned scores according to the value assignment standards for the indicators outlined in the appendix. After scoring the corresponding secondary indicators for each transmission tower, the entropy method can be employed to determine the weight of each indicator. The weighted average of the secondary indicators is then calculated, which yields the score for each primary indicator. Based on these scores, a corresponding analysis can be provided.

Discussion and suggestions

(1) Set elastic patrol period.

On the basis of comprehensively grasping the operation status of transmission lines, the patrol period shall be appropriately extended or shortened. DL /T741 Operating Regulations for Overhead Transmission Lines stipulates that the normal inspection period of transmission lines is once a month42. However, with the increasing scale of power grid erection and the longer operation mileage, the demand for improving the inspection efficiency is increasing. Through the analysis of the safety vulnerability of the power grid, the vulnerability and resistance of each transmission tower of the line can be obtained. For areas or transmission towers with inconvenient traffic, high difficulty in patrol inspection but low vulnerability or high resistance of the transmission tower, the patrol inspection period can be appropriately extended, such as 90 #, 91 #, 92 # transmission towers with danger index lower than 25 (as shown in Fig. 25). For transmission towers with high danger or low resistance, the inspection period can be appropriately shortened to ensure that these transmission towers are in normal working conditions, such as 168 # and 125 # transmission towers with danger index higher than 50 and 101 # and 104 # transmission towers with low resistance index (as shown in Figs. 25 and 27). These transmission towers are more vulnerable to disasters and accidents than other transmission towers on the line, or are large-span and small-angle tangent towers, and their environment is greatly affected by corrosion and other factors, It’s components are more vulnerable to damage or fatigue43.

(2) Carry out fine patrol inspection.

Determine key patrol inspection disaster types by season44. Through danger analysis, most disasters or accidents have strong seasonal distribution characteristics. Spring patrol inspection should focus on the impact of wind damage on the transmission tower, as well as the icing of the line caused by special climate changes such as the late spring cold, the warming of the temperature in spring, and the increase of human activities. The patrol inspection in densely populated areas should be strengthened to prevent the impact of foreign objects on the operation of the power grid caused by human activities such as kite flying and tree planting. Winter is characterized by low temperature, foggy and high degree of pollution. The winter is relatively dry. In addition to the influence of coal heating, the degree of air pollution has increased compared with other seasons. In case of heavy fog, pollution flashover is likely to occur. At the same time, the winter temperature is relatively low. Especially, the average temperature of January in the area where the research line is located is extremely in line with the temperature standard suitable for icing. Once the humidity and wind speed conditions meet the requirements, the line icing disaster is likely to occur, and the icing leads to the increase of wind area, causing secondary disasters such as line galloping. In the period of severe climate change, combined with the focus of seasonal patrol inspection, the efficiency of patrol inspection can be improved and the safety of power grid can be guaranteed.

Refine the inspection contents according to disaster types. For example, the impact of wind disaster on the transmission tower is mainly concentrated on the swing angle of fittings, bolts and conductors. The frequent change of wind direction will cause the wear of fittings, especially the insulator connection fittings. The lateral swing of conductors will easily lead to the loosening of the tower bolts. When the wind is too strong, it will also lead to the wind deviation tripping. Therefore, the key inspection contents for the wind disaster will be determined45. Patrol inspection of pollution flashover mainly includes observation and measurement of insulator surface pollution. According to the different types of disasters, we can determine the focus of targeted patrol inspection, cooperate with seasonal patrol inspection, and further improve the efficiency of patrol inspection.

(3) Improve the intrinsic safety level of power grid.

Installation of safety guards based on safety vulnerability characteristics46. For example, the tower materials of 28 #, 65 # and other transmission towers with high danger to theft shall be subject to anti-unloading treatment, and anti-theft bolts shall be installed at the section number close to the ground (as shown in Fig. 23). For transmission towers with high danger to floods such as 149 # and 79 # and high danger to landslides such as 41 #(as shown in Fig. 21), effective anti-erosion measures can be taken to reduce their danger, such as setting drainage ditches and making foundation protection for transmission towers. The insulator suspension mode shall be improved to V type near the poles and towers with high danger to icing and pollution flashover. According to different disaster characteristics, technical means shall be used to improve the safe operation level of power grid. Reasonably follow the warning signs and warning signs. On the one hand, ensure the standardization and integrity of the pole number plate and warning plate of the transmission tower itself. On the other hand, warning signs in line with the situation should be set near the corresponding dangerous points, such as setting warning elevation on the road near the 83 # transmission tower with important crossing, and installing warning signs of “high voltage danger, no fishing” along the 111 # and 79 # transmission towers near the water area (as shown in Fig. 5).

(4) Strengthen scientific and technological support.

Select the appropriate online monitoring device according to the characteristics of danger and resistance. The transmission line online monitoring device can be divided into several types according to different monitoring purposes, such as meteorological monitoring, conductor temperature monitoring, line sag and wind deflection monitoring, tower tilt monitoring, anti-theft alarm monitoring, etc. Comprehensive online monitoring will not only increase the cost of line operation and use, but also cause waste of resources. Therefore, different types of online monitoring devices should be installed according to the vulnerability attributes of different transmission towers to achieve reasonable and optimal resource allocation. For example, the conductor temperature monitoring device is installed on 152 #, 153 # and other transmission towers with high icing danger (as shown in Fig. 18), and the tower tilt monitoring device is installed on 144 #, 143 # and other large-span and corner towers with low resistance, so as to grasp the line operation status remotely and online, and go to the site in time to understand and deal with the transmission towers with abnormal parameters.

(5) Optimize emergency supplies reserve.

From the analysis of safety vulnerability results, it can be seen that recoverability and susceptibility are the two items that account for a large proportion of safety vulnerability. Improving recoverability and reducing danger are the most effective ways to reduce the gap between safety vulnerabilities of transmission towers. Densely populated areas and transmission towers far away from the road are more difficult parts in the process of power emergency response. Reasonably allocate emergency supplies47. Targeted emergency repair equipment corresponding to disasters shall be allocated nearby. For example, the danger of wind disaster and icing near 100 # tower is relatively low, and the danger of pollution flashover is relatively high (as shown in Fig. 29). More emergency repair equipment and components for pollution flashover accidents shall be stored in the nearest emergency repair station of this section to realize the rationalization of emergency resource allocation. Improve the emergency repair capability. In the research line, the danger of wind disaster and pollution flashover of the transmission tower located in the densely populated area is relatively high, while the danger of icing and other disasters is relatively low. Therefore, it is necessary to improve the response ability and knowledge reserve of the emergency repair personnel in the area to disasters such as wind disaster and pollution flashover, develop the emergency decision support system, optimize the emergency route, minimize the repair time, and reduce the impact on the surrounding social activities, so as to improve the recoverability of the power grid in the face of accident disasters and reduce its susceptibility.

Conclusion and outlook

Conclusion

The following results are obtained in this paper:

Based on the safety vulnerability model, the evaluation index system of power grid safety vulnerability is constructed. The safety vulnerability model is introduced into the electric power field, and the power grid safety vulnerability evaluation index system is constructed from the four levels of danger, susceptibility, resistance and recoverability. Through literature research, the evaluation method and basis of 52 secondary indicators are defined, and the weight of each indicator is determined by entropy method.

Methods and ideas for processing raw data using geographic information technology-based software. The coordinate information of transmission towers is obtained by geographic location capture and other means, and the methods of using ArcGIS software extraction, interpolation and nearest neighbor analysis to process four types of raw data, such as geospatial, geographic environment, meteorological environment and social environment, are given.

187 500 kV transmission towers from Luohe City to Zhoukou City in Henan Province were selected for example study. The safety vulnerability distribution of the 187 towers was analyzed, and targeted countermeasure suggestions were given for different safety vulnerability characteristics from the perspective of line operation and inspection and emergency repair.

In conclusion, this study establishes a comprehensive power grid safety vulnerability assessment framework incorporating four key dimensions: susceptibility, sensitivity, resistance, and resilience. By integrating the entropy weight method with GIS-based spatial analysis techniques, a multi-dimensional and spatially refined assessment approach is proposed. Taking the 500 kV transmission lines in Henan Province as a case study, the model effectively captures the differentiated vulnerability levels of transmission towers and identifies critical risk factors that impact grid stability. These findings provide a robust basis for implementing differentiated inspection protocols, targeted maintenance strategies, and focused mitigation of weak links in the power grid.

Compared with existing vulnerability assessment approaches—many of which rely on structural topology or subjective weighting—this study demonstrates significant improvements in three aspects. First, it introduces a more objective weighting mechanism, where the entropy method reflects the inherent variability among indicators and eliminates the arbitrariness of expert judgment. Second, it constructs a systematically comprehensive indicator framework, integrating natural hazards, geographic conditions, socio-environmental contexts, and structural characteristics, thereby addressing the limitations of incomplete indicator coverage in prior models. Third, it enhances operational applicability, leveraging GIS tools to achieve spatial visualization and classification of vulnerable segments, thus improving the practicality and precision of risk identification. Accordingly, the proposed method outperforms conventional approaches in terms of theoretical rigor, evaluation accuracy, and practical relevance, offering a scalable and adaptable solution to support the enhancement of grid resilience and the modernization of safety management.

Limitations and prospects

The expected goal of this paper has been basically achieved, but due to the limitations of objective factors such as personal level and data acquisition, the research still has the following aspects that can be further improved.

In this paper, the ease of access to data is considered and the accuracy of selection of some data had to be partially discarded. The replacement of some of the indicators can further improve the accuracy of the safety vulnerability assessment, for example, the study of lightning danger uses ground flash density and ground flash intensity instead of the number of thunderstorm days, which can obtain more accurate lightning danger assessment results.

The disaster chain should be further studied. The research on the disaster chain in this paper is relatively simple. For example, the slope factor is taken into account when evaluating the danger to earthquakes, but it is still necessary to further study the relationship between disasters and secondary disasters in the future, and constantly enrich and improve the current safety vulnerability assessment index system.

Develop visualization software for power grid safety vulnerability assessment. This paper has spent a lot of energy in the processing of tens of thousands of original data. The processing ideas of different original data have strong logic. The input of original data and the output of vulnerability evaluation results can be realized through programming. At the same time, the evaluation results of each transmission tower are presented in a visual interface, and the patrol list of each transmission tower is automatically generated, and the allocation suggestions of emergency resources are given.

urn:contentItem:6DCC-WKG1-DY68-1108-00000-00Red Flag Warning Issued As Raging NJ Brush Fire Sends Smoke Into NYC2024-11-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:07:19ZLexisNexisRed Flag Warning Issued As Raging NJ Brush Fire Sends Smoke Into NYCJenna Sundel

A forest fire started burning in New Jersey Thursday night as a red flag warning was issued for the region.

Firefighters are working to contain a New Jersey brush fire sending smoke into New York City.

The fire broke out on the Palisades in Englewood Cliffs Thursday night. The New Jersey Forest Fire Service said the fire spans 19 acres and is 30% contained as of 7:36 a.m. Friday.

A red flag warning has been issued from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. for most of New Jersey, New York and Connecticut due to dry and windy conditions. The New Jersey Forest Fire Service has designated the current fire risk as extreme for the entire state.

Dozens of firefighters are responding to the blaze near exit 1 on the Palisades Parkway. One northbound lane on the roadway remains closed.

The fire is burning in a heavily wooded area between the Palisades Parkway and the Hudson River. No structures are threatened by the blaze, according to the New Jersey Forest Fire Service.

The agency also plans to use a helicopter capable of dropping 350 gallons of water.

Officials said the fire is unlikely to expand significantly. The cause of the blaze is under investigation.

The FDNY said it responded to reports of smoke, according to CBS News New York.

October was the driest month on record in the New York City area with less than an inch of rain.

The fire risk could remain moderate-to-high Saturday before decreasing Sunday into Monday, as rain is expected in the region.

At least three other wildfires have spread across New Jersey recently, including one in Jackson Township that is about 60% contained after burning 350 acres. Six homes near Six Flags Great Adventure were evacuated as a result of the blaze. No injuries were reported and the cause of the fire is under investigation.

The Bethany Run wildfire in Burlington and Camden Counties has burned more than 300 acres. The blaze is 50% contained. No structures have been evacuated, but 104 are threatened.

Another fire, deemed the Pheasant Run Wildfire, is burning in the Glassboro Wildlife Management Area in Gloucester County.

New Jersey officials have placed temporary restrictions prohibiting all fires not contained in an elevated stove and fueled by propane, natural gas, gas or electricity. Under the fire ban, wood or charcoal fires and kerosene are not allowed on private or public property. Bonfires and fireworks are also banned.

What's a Red Flag Warning?

A weather service will issue a red flag warning when there is an increased risk of fire in an area due to warm temperatures, low humidity and strong winds.

The warning helps alert fire managers and officials to keep an eye out for wildfires and stop any planned burns.

The warnings are commonly issued in the fall and spring seasons.

urn:contentItem:6CDJ-BT31-DY7R-R0TP-00000-00Report Summarizes Networks Study Findings from Nanjing Forestry University (A Forest Fire Smoke Monitoring System Based on a Lightweight Neural Network for Edge Devices)2024-07-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:07:19ZLexisNexisNETWORKSReport Summarizes Networks Study Findings from Nanjing Forestry University (A Forest Fire Smoke Monitoring System Based on a Lightweight Neural Network for Edge Devices)


2024 JUL 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Network Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on networks. According to news reporting from Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Forest resources are one of the indispensable resources of the earth, which are the basis for the survival and development of human society. With the swift advancements in computer vision and artificial intelligence technology, the utilization of deep learning for smoke detection has achieved remarkable results."


Financial supporters for this research include Postgraduate Research And Practice Innovation Program of Jiangsu Province; National Key R&D Program of China.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing Forestry University: "However, the existing deep learning models have poor performance in forest scenes and are difficult to deploy because of numerous parameters. Hence, we introduce an optimized forest fire smoke monitoring system for embedded edge devices based on a lightweight deep learning model. The model makes full use of the multi-scale variable attention mechanism of Transformer architecture to strengthen the ability of image feature extraction. Considering the needs of application scenarios, we propose an improved lightweight network model LCNet for feature extraction, which can reduce the parameters and enhance detecting ability. In order to improve running speed, a simple semi-supervised label knowledge distillation scheme is used to enhance the overall detection capability. Finally, we design and implement a forest fire smoke detection system on an embedded device, including the Jetson NX hardware platform, high-definition camera, and detection software system. The lightweight model is transplanted to the embedded edge device to achieve rapid forest fire smoke detection."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Also, an asynchronous processing framework is designed to make the system highly available and robust. The improved model reduces three-fourths of the parameters and increases speed by 3.4 times with similar accuracy to the original model. This demonstrates that our system meets the precision demand and detects smoke in time."
For more information on this research see: A Forest Fire Smoke Monitoring System Based on a Lightweight Neural Network for Edge Devices. Forests, 2024,15(7). (Forests - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/forests/). The publisher for Forests is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/f15071092.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Jingwen Huang, College of Information Science and Technology, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Huizhou Yang, Yunfei Liu, Han Liu.
